loans.name: Pon

texts.en: Mrs. Pon P. makes a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. Mrs. Pon P. has raised a lot of piglets, which she sells to buyers four months after she begins raising them. Mrs. Pon P. is married to Mr. Phor Lorm, a 39-year-old construction worker. The couple is blessed with six children, none of whom are married. In order to earn extra profit and to improve her standard of living, Mrs. Pon P. will use the loan to buy more pigs to sell. She will also use a portion of the funds to make a cage for feeding the pigs.

loans.use: To buy more pigs to sell and to make a cage for feeding pigs

loans.name: Kunthy

texts.en:
Miss. Kunthy C., 40, is single. She lives with her niece on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Kunthy is a silk weaver. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She has had one previous Kiva loan. Now  she is asking for her second loan of $100 to purchase weaving materials needed to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials

loans.name: Orn

texts.en:
Mrs. Orn S. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Sophak Tit, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  They have been married since 2004 and have no children yet. 

Mrs. Orn S. sells bananas and mangos.  She buys them under contract from fellow villagers and transports them to sell in Phnom Penh market.  Her husband is a wooden-house builder. 

Orn applied for a Kiva loan one time before.  She hopes to continue her business so she is requesting another loan of 500 USD to purchase mangos under contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase mangos under contract for resale.

loans.name: Sothea

texts.en:
Mr. Sothea N. (pictured here) and his wife, Mrs. Savet Rin, live along National Road Number Six about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.  They have been married since 1995 and have three children, two sons and one daughter. 

Sothea and her husband run a grocery store from their home.  In addition, the couple also grows rice and vegetables on their farmland in the village. Sothea is requesting a loan of 400 USD to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his rice and vegetable farm.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain his rice and vegetable farm.

loans.name: Yory

texts.en:
Mrs. Yory Y. is 31 years old and her husband, Mr. Sros Nhean is 30 years old. They have been married since 2000 and have one son and two daughters. The family lives in a village along National Road Number Six about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Yory and her husband are rice farmers. Her husband is a fisherman as well. She is asking for her first loan of $700 to purchase a motorized hand tiller to use on her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase a motorized hand tiller to use on her rice farm

loans.name: Roman

texts.en:
Roman D. is married and has two sons. He owns a small business offering auto repair services in the town of Ivano-Frankivsk. Roman specializes in fixing engines. His income is about 7000 UAH a month.

Roman started this business 16 years ago in his own small garage. He has always loved to deal with car and motorcycle engines. Roman does his work with a high quality and guarantees his services. This business is the main source of income for his family.

Roman is requesting a loan of 11000 UAH to purchase equipment for his business. Roman’s goal is to fix the apartment where he and his family live.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for his auto repair business

loans.name: Sophea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophea S., 40 and her husband, Proeung Un, 46, have been married since 1989 and have one son and two daughters. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sophea is a silk weaver. Her husband is a farmer. She is requesting a loan of US $300 to purchase weaving materials for her business.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials

loans.name: Yom

texts.en:
Yom S. is 54 years old and a resident of Battambang Province. She is married and has five children, four of them are single, and the one remaining is married and living in her own house. Yom's husband’s name is Morn Meit. He works as a farmer, and he is also a fisherman.

Yom earns a living raising ducks in a cage behind her house. She raises ducks to produce eggs and sells the eggs to people who come to buy in bulk at her house. This family can earn a profit of approximately $2 per day. 

Currently, two of her children have an opportunity to work overseas, but they need money to pay for the document fee. Because her savings are not enough to make it possible, Yom S. would like to use her loan to pay for her children's document fees.

loans.use: To pay for document fee

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya M. is married with an 11-year-old daughter. She sells women’s shoes at the central market in Melitopol town. Nataliya started this business eight years ago using her parents' help. She enjoys selling women’s shoes and plans to develop this business further. 

Nataliya has used micro loans in the past. She finds them very helpful for her business. This time Nataliya is requesting a loan of 10000 UAH to increase the assortment of seasonal merchandise. She hopes to receive additional income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To increase the assortment of seasonal merchandise

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B., from the village of Nuesa, is 33 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Gina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be Gina's second loan from ASKI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Sari Karya Group

texts.en:
Ni Ketut N. is a 46-year-old woman living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Ketut is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Sari Karya (PK-10362).


Ni Ketut is widowed and has three children, two have already finished their education in Senior High School and the other one is still in Elementary School.  To make a living, Ni Ketut owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  Ni Ketut has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 300,000 IDR a month from these activities.

Ni Ketut N. now has no husband. Her husband died three months ago because of illness. Although she has been left a widow, Ni Ketut N. did not grieve too long; she kept the spirit of doing business. She still pays for the school needs for one of her children. The two children who have graduated from school are still looking for a job. She hopes that with the help of a loan for her business, she will be able to support her family.


In 2010, Ni Ketut joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Ketut has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500,000 IDR from MUK.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.  She is now requesting a new loan of 1,500,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Ketut plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Ketut N. (0) merupakan 46 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Ketut adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 15 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Sari Karya (PK-10362).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Ketut sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 5 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Ketut menghasilkan sekitar 0,300 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Ketut bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Ketut telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1.500.000 IDR dari MUK.  Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk berinvestasi dengan mengembangkan bisnis.  Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1.500.000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.


  "

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Las Aguilas Group

texts.es:
Para  Feliza el trabajo siempre ha sido parte de su vida uno de los últimos fue en un restaurante  fue ahí donde  conoció un amigo que le ofreció el  traspaso de su negocio un locutorio, la oferta era interesante es así que no lo pensó mucho y con sus ahorros compro el traspaso y empezó a trabajar, fue una buena decisión por que el negocio ya contaba con clientela lo único que hizo fue mejorar la atención y ofrecer algunas otras cosas como la venta de tarjetas telefónicas, recargas virtuales, etc.  Al final resulto una buena inversión se siente feliz por que sus ingresos son de mucha ayuda para su familia y su sustento, lo que mas quieres ahora es trasladar su negocio a la zona donde vive ya que se le hace difícil el traslado además de ahorrar el costo por  alquiler ya que en el lugar donde vive el pago por local es mas barato, ella usara  su préstamo para invertir en recargas para celulares esto le genera buenas ganancias, su grupo se llama “LAS AGUILAS” pertenecen a EDAPROSPO hace muchos años y ella esta particularmente agradecida por que ha visto su negocio crecer cada día.

*Feliza esta sentada es la cuarta de la derecha, en la foto tambien aparece una Sra invitada.
texts.en:
For Feliza, work has always been a part of her life.  One of her latest jobs was in a restaurant.  This is where she met a friend who offered to sell her his public telephone business as a going concern.  The offer was interesting.  She didn't think twice and, with her savings, she bought the business and began to work.  It was a good decision because the business already had a customer base.  The only thing she had to do was improve the service and offer a few other things such as the sale of phone cards, virtual top ups, etc.

In the end it turned out to be a good investment.  She feels happy because her income is a great help for supporting her family.  What she would like now is to move her business to the area where she lives as it is difficult for her to commute.  What is more, she would save on rent since where she lives the premises are cheaper.  She will use her loan to invest in top ups for cell phones.  This makes her good profits.  Her group is called “Las Águilas” (The Eagles).  They have been members of EDAPROSPO for many years and she is particularly grateful because she has seen her business grow every day.

* Feliza is sat down, fourth from the right.  There is also a guest in the photo.

loans.use: Virtual top ups for calls

loans.name: Melony

texts.en:
Melony G. is from the village of Nuesa, Roxas, Isabela. She is 36 years old. Melony is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Melony owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling fish balls and other dimsums to the local community. Melony has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Melony joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melony has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Melony is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Melony from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita F. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 54 years old. Teresita is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 33,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Pelesia

texts.en:
Pelesia is a widowed woman who owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. 

For the past twenty years, she has been selling fresh fish from home and door to door. In addition she also operates a retail shop selling sugar, wheat flour, maize flour, and cooking oil to her neighbours and passersby. Pelesia faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the summer hot season, the cost of fresh-water fish rises compared to in the rainy winter season where the buying price is lower. She hopes to open a shop to sell fish in the future. 

With the Kshs 60,000 she wants to purchase a bundle of fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of fish for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Stella has a business selling cold drinks, which she has had for 3 years.         

To help expand her business, Stella has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase sodas and beers.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Stella hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Stella hopes to buy a fridge. Stella is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning music, dance, and drama.

loans.use: sodas, beers

loans.name: Bolormaa

texts.en:
Bolormaa L. is 41 years old and lives with her husband and two sons in an apartment in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. Her youngest son attends a local secondary school while her husband operates a taxi service in their town. Bolormaa manages a meat retail business in the local market in her town. She began her business in 2005 with working capital of 150,000 MNT. 

After several years of hard work and having grown a loyal customer base, her working capital now exceeds 1,200,000 MNT. She has built a stable operation with many permanent customers. She would like to expand her business in the future. Bolormaa is an honest and hard-working woman. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more meat to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Mariam has a business of selling clothes, which she has had for one year.         

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase a rental shop.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Mariam hopes to own a retail shop.    

Mariam is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to protect herself and have good hygiene.

loans.use: a rental shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: charcoal

loans.name: Clemencia

texts.en:
This is Clemencia A., 57, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Rodolfo A., a tailor and her business partner. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Clemencia operates a variety store and a tailor shop where her husband is the senior tailor and overseer. A variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She will also invest a portion of the loan to buy tailoring supplies like fabric, etc. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Clemencia dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages and invest a portion of the loan to buy tailoring supplies

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is the rent.

She has operated a second-hand clothes selling business for over seven years, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. Jackline faces a major challenge of seasonality and difficulty of transport incurred when moving from door to door. She hopes to open a stall to sell clothes and window curtains out of in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance to improve her business. With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase a bale of second-hand clothes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of second-hand clothes for resale

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has one child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Jane has a business selling charcoal, which she has had for three years.  She also sells food.  

To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase charcoal.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jane hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  

In the future, Jane hopes to own a retail shop.  Jane is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to handle business.

loans.use: charcoal

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en:
Myagmarsuren G. is 30 years old and lives with his wife and three-year-old son in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His son is in a local kindergarten while his wife works as a cook in a local cafe. 

Myagmarsuren owns a taxi service in his town. He started his business in 2008 after purchasing his own car. In his town, there is no public transportation service therefore demand for taxi service is high. After a short period of operation, he has expanded his customer base and earned a good reputation among the local people. He has found success in his business and his earnings have enabled him not only to buy a plot of land and fence but also to start building a house for his familyoin it. Moreover, his family's standard of living has been improving greatly. 

Myagmarsuren is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to finish construction of his house as well as purchase a necessary spare parts for his taxi.

loans.use: To finish construction of his house and purchase necessary spare parts

loans.name: Felly

texts.en:
Felly V. is a married woman who lives in Purok Makawiwili, Brgy. Mabini, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a tricycle transport business. Her husband Rodolfo, who is 48 years old, works as a driver to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have two children who are 23 and 24 years old. 

Felly joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 20 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Felly has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 35,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 21st  loan, she is borrowing PHP 40,000, which she intends to buy stock for the general store and perform maintenance for a tricycle so that she can continue to save up for future expansion of her business. Felly V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.	 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell to customers

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.   Jackline has a business selling charcoal, which she has had for 2 years.         

To help expand her business, Jackline has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase charcoal.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Jackline hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  

In the future, Jackline hopes to become a teacher.Jackline is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to save money.

loans.use: charcoal

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a thirty-nine-year-old, married with six children living in her own home in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is in the retail shop business and over a period of twenty years, she has managed to educate her children and buy land as well from the profits of her business. Although she is faced with a big challenge of limited capital, she still hopes for the best in her business. Margret needs a loan to purchase sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap to sell at her shop.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, salt, cooking oil, and soap for resale

loans.name: Dolgorjav

texts.en:
Dolgorjav L. is 35 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Arhangai province, central Mongolia. She and her daughters live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent. All three of her children attend a local secondary school and her husband operates a firewood and coal trading business, using his own truck, to support his family.

 At first, she attended a felt souvenirs training seminar and purchased a combing machine with her working capital in 2001. Dolgorjav has been producing a variety of felt products for many years and has gained significant experience. Today her working capital has reached 1,500,000 MNT. She credits her business success to her hard work and good customer service. She sells her products to foreign tourists through the partnership. 

Dolgorjav is a honest woman and says, "My dream is to have my own factory for the future." She is requesting a 1,750,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more materials for her felt production.

loans.use: To purchase more materials

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
This is Erlinda R., 54, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Mario R., a maintenance man. At this time, both of them are working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Erlinda operates a general merchandise store where she mostly sells accessories. Her products range from aesthetic accessories like headbands, clips and such, to hardware like cell phone housing, chargers, screwdrivers, wrenches, etc. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece.  Her store is located by her home.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Erlinda dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie B. is a 37-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating one business venture: a fishing business.  She lives in Sitio Tabunok, Brgy. Tiglawigan, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000. Rosemarie is now borrowing PHP 12,000 so that she can continue to purchase fishing gear and an engine for the pump boat.   This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rosemarie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase a new engine for their pump boat

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon E. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 52 years old. Corazon is married. To make a living, Corazon owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Corazon has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Corazon joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Corazon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Corazon is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Corazon from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Baasanhuu

texts.en:
Baasanhuu R. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in an apartment. All three children attend a local school.

Baasanhuu operates a meat retail business in the local market in her town. She began her business in 2005 with working capital of 150,000 MNT. After several years of hard work and with a loyal customer base, her working capital now exceeds 700,000 MNT. 

Over the years, she has gained a significant experience and many permanent customers. She would like to expand their business in the future and own her own livestock. 

Baasanhuu is a hard-working and honest woman and is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more meat to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is forty-three years old, married with six children and living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She lives in her own permanent house and her family dream is to educate her children. Dorothy operates a retail shop besides her pasturing and has been operating it for the past ten years. Her business dream is to have her retail shop turned into wholesale. 

Dorothy intends to use this loan to purchase sugar, soap, and cooking oil for resale at her shop.

loans.use: Purchasing sugar, soap, and cooking oil for resale

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella B. is 39 years old, married, and supports her family by operating a fishing business. She lives in Purok Pasayan, Brgy. Tomongtong, EB. Magalona, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF, and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 9,000 PHP. Bella is currently borrowing 13,000 PHP so that she can purchase a new engine and crab nets. This will be her sixth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 14,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Bella aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon--a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a community member who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase new engine and crab net

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ulpiana

texts.en:
Ulpiana M. is from the village of Bulwa, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 71 years old. Ulpiana is widowed. To make a living, Ulpiana owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling bananas and coconuts in the local community. Ulpiana has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2001, Ulpiana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ulpiana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional bananas and coconuts to  buy and sell. Ulpiana is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the 5th loan taken out by Ulpiana from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Mahmadullo

texts.ru: Иброхимов Махмадулло проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 23 года. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей. Имеет магазин, где продает продукты питания, духи и одежду. То есть у него магазин со смешенным ассортиментом. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 4 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Mahmadullo I. lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 23 years old. He is married and has two children. He has secondary education. He is a saleman and has a store where he sells groceries, perfumes and clothing. In other words his store has a variety of different products. He has been doing this business for four years now. He is talking out the loan to increase inventory circulation and sales.

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Piseth

texts.en:
Mr. Piseth S. (in the photo), 25 and his wife, Mrs. Ratha Un, 19, live in a village a long National Road Number six about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2010 and just have a son.  

Piseth is a fisherman. His wife sells vegetables, but she stopped for a while because she just delivered a baby. Piseth is asking for his first loan of $300 to repair his fishing equipment.

loans.use: To repair his fishing equipment.

loans.name: Stanley Murigi

texts.en:
Stanley is a 49 year old farmer who he is married to Lucy, a business lady and they are blessed with 12 children.  Stanley has been doing farming for the past seven years.  His monthly income is KES 7,000 which he uses to support his family.  

With the loan he has applied for, he plans to purchase fertilizer, herbicides, seedlings and manures.  Stanley intends to use the anticipated profit from the business to expand to coffee farming.  He is applying for his second loan with Kadet after he successfully paid off the first. His hopes and dreams are to improve the living standard for his family and to educate his children.

loans.use: To purchase  fertilizers, herbicides, seedlings and manures.

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
This is Lily D., 41, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Victor D., a seafarer. They have three children enrolled in elementary school. At this time, both of them are working hard to continually provide income for their children’s education and for everyday expenses.

Lily operates a ready-to-wear items business and a general merchandise store where she mostly sells groceries, toiletries and beverages. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece.  Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Lily dreams of being able to renovate her house soon, with all of her work with the business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more  products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Amigas Por Siempre Group

texts.es:
Durante mucho tiempo Nelly ha trabajado en diferentes oficios pero debido a la exigencia y el esfuerzo que requerían D. ella hizo que deje los trabajos mas aun por dedicarse a su familia, ella quería trabajar por su cuenta utilizando sus ratos libres para no descuidar a sus hijos fue una buena amiga la que le enseño a vender diversos productos por campañas, así empezó con los turrones un dulce muy popular en el Perú que tiene mucha demanda los meses D. octubre, realmente le fue bien en sus ventas sus turrones tuvieron mucha demanda, ahora esta abocada a la campaña que viene.  la venta D. panetones por navidad  ella quiere invertir el dinero D. su préstamo abasteciéndose D. este producto sabe que tendrá mucha demanda, para la época D. verano también quiere dedicarse a la venta D. helados su suegra le ha ofrecido un espacio para que pueda empezar  este negocio, Nelly es feliz por que trabajando pueD. ayudar a su hija que estudia en la universidad y lo que la hace mas feliz es sentirse útil a sus 49 años, con su trabajo dentro del grupo como secretaria también se siente satisfecha.

*Nelly viste polo mostaza
texts.en:
Nelly has worked in different trades for a long time.  However, owing to the demands and effort which they required from her, she gave the jobs up in order to devote herself to her family.  She wanted to work for herself in her spare time so that she didn't have to neglect her children.  It was a good friend who taught her to sell various seasonal products.  She began selling nougat (a very popular sweet in Peru which is in high demand in October).  Her nougat sales went well.  Her nougat was in high demand.  Now she is getting ready for the upcoming season, selling panettones for Christmas.  She would like to invest her loan in stocking up with this product as she knows that there will be a lot of demand.  In the summer season she also wants to sell ice cream.  Her mother-in-law has offered her a space so that she can begin this business.  Nelly is happy because by working she can help her daughter who is studying at university.  What makes her even happier is feeling useful at 49 years of age.  Her work as secretary of her group also makes her feel satisfied.

*Nelly is the woman wearing the mustard-colored polo shirt.

loans.use: To buy panettones for the holidays

loans.name: Dina

texts.en:
Dina Y. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 41 years old. Dina is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Dina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Dina has been engaged in her business for over 21 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Dina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 33,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Dina is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Dina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Jesmen

texts.en:
Jesmen S. is from the village of Talon, Gingoog City. She is 27 years old. Jesmen is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Jesmen owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods & junk foods in the local community. Jesmen has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jesmen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jesmen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products sell. Jesmen is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Jesmen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda P. is a married woman who lives in Hda. Banilad 1, Brgy. Nangka, EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  general store, e-loading and food vending businesses. Her husband Reynaldo, who is 52 years old, works as a Guard Supervisor to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have one child who is 17 years old. 

Brenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Brenda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 21,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 24,000, which she intends to buy stock for the general store so that she can continue to save up for future home repairs and expansion of her businesses.

 Brenda P. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Sam-Un

texts.en:
Sam-un V. is 58 years old and his wife,  Kimtheng Phorn is 56 years old.  They have six daughters. The family lives along National Road Number Six about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sam-un is a chef in a restaurant in Phnom Penh. His wife stays at home and does housework. Sam-un is asking for his first loan of $1,000 to purchase lattice to repair his house.

Mr. Sam-un was not available for the picture, so his wife is pictured.

loans.use: To purchase lattice to repair his house

loans.name: Shakirah

texts.en:
Shakirah N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Shakirah has a business of selling charcoal, which she has had for two years.  She also sells tap water.  

To help expand her business, Shakirah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase charcoal.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Shakirah hopes to generate greater profits and take care of herself.  In the future, Shakirah hopes to become a hairdresser.   Shakirah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to earn money.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal

loans.name: Gertrude

texts.en:
Gertrude is a forty-five-year-old agriculturalist, married with four children living in their own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her family dream is to have a permanent house and educate their children. She has been in agriculture for the last nine years now.  She said she started with just a little savings to get her where she is now. She hopes to have a zero grazing farm in future, despite the challenges of price fluctuations. 

Gertrude needs the loan to expand her farm livestock by buying more cattle to sell when mature.

loans.use: Buying more cattle for her farm to sell when mature

loans.name: Malingi

texts.en:
Malingi K. is a thirty-two-year-old dressmaker in Mtaani Kilifi. He is married to Joyce Juma who adds to his income and together they have three children. He has been in this business for the last two years and has done great. 

Being his first loan with KADET, he plans to purchase cloth and materials for making dresses to sell during the coming festive season. He plans to use the anticipated profit to pay school fees for his children. Malingi hopes to increase his cash flow in future.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials for making dresses

loans.name: Hay

texts.en:
Hay V. is a 62-year-old farmer who lives in Battambang Province. Hay V.’s husband died many years ago and she has been living with her child who helps her in her farming business. She has a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. 

Hay V. uses this land to grow different kinds of crops. She planted rice and vegetable crops two months ago, but her crops are not growing well because they need more fertilizer. To remedy the situation, she would like a loan to buy a few sacks of fertilizer to make her crops grow well.

loans.use: To buy a few sacks of fertilizer for her crops

loans.name: Divina Rigor's Group

texts.en:
Divina R. is from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 40 years old. Divina is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Divina is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Divina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens to produce eggs for sale. Divina has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Divina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Divina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Divina is requesting a new loan of 18,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Divina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao C. (in the photo), 56, is a widow. She lives with her grandson and granddaughter in a small village near the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Mao has been running a grocery store in her village for five years. She is requesting a loan of US$ 500 to expand her grocery store and provide capital for her sister’s farming business.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store and provide capital for her sister’s farming business

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is a 38-year-old man living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He is married with six children and lives in his own permanent house. Patrick’s dream is educating his children and boosting his wife’s business as well. He been cutting firewood and selling it to factories for the last year and his business has withstood the test of time. He started with an initial capital of 800,000 shillings but he has so far realized more than 2,000,000 shillings from the business. This has enabled him to build a permanent house, buy cows and household assets as well. Patrick needs this loan to settle transport expenses for his firewood to various factories.

loans.use: To settle transport expenses for his firewood to various factories.

loans.name: Limford

texts.en:
Limford T. lives in the village of Minsapinit, Gingoog City. He is 42 years old, married, has two school-aged children and makes a living by raising livestock. He also uses his motorcycle to run a business on the side providing transportation services to people in his community. He has worked in these fields for more than four years and earns about 10,000 PHP a month.

Last year, Limford joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He has successfully repaid three previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one, for 12,000 PHP, to buy livestock feed and other supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue expanding his business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Jenniffer

texts.en: Jenniffer is a 29-year-old married lady with three children living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. Her family dream is to develop her business and educate her children. Jennifer is a tailor. In four years, she has managed to purchase a sweater machine and a sewing machine. She has the challenge of limited capital and seasonal tenders. That is why she intends to use the loan to pay school fees for her children to avoid being chased from school.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a married and has two children, both of whom attend school. He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped-in water. His greatest monthly expense is buying food for his family. 

For the last several years, Peter has made a living by running a store where he sells items to people who live in his community. He also runs a business on the side where he grows and sells vegetables. His main challenge is that his income varies by season, and he would like to resolve that problem in the future by opening a retail business.  

Peter recently joined Yehu to get financial help to improve his business. He has applied for a loan for Kshs 30,000 to buy maize flour, sugar, beans, rice and phone cards to sell to his customers.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, sugar, beans, rice and phone cards to sell to his customers

loans.name: Sreypach

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypach P. (who we see in this photo), 25, and her husband, Mr. Channy Sorn, 28, have been married since 2003 and have three sons. One of them attends school and other two are still living at home. The family lives in a village near the Mekong River about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sreypach makes a living selling fruits (such as mangos, bananas and papaya), buying them under contract from her fellow villagers and transporting them for sale in a Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a construction worker. Sreypach hopes to expand her business by buying additional fruits to resell, and is applying for a loan for $600 to make this possible.

loans.use: To buy fruit to sell to her customers

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty M. is 26 years old and makes a living selling fish in Junju Kilifi. She is married to M. Matsaki and together they are blessed with two children. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend, and is applying for her first loan to buy bigger frying pans and more fish to sell. She will use the additional income made possible by this loan to increase her income further by buying a cow. She hopes that loans from KADET will allow her family to live a better life.

loans.use: to buy bigger frying pans and more fish to sell

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta S. lives in the village of Malibud, Gingoog City. She is 46 years old, married and has seven school-aged children. She earns a living by running a sari-sari (or variety) retail store where she sells items people use daily such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, snacks, eggs, breads, biscuits, instant noodles and canned goods. She has been in this line of work for more than 10 years and earns about 8,000 PHP a month.

Earlier this year, Julieta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid two previous loans from HSPFI and is applying for a new one, for 7,000 PHP,  to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income generated by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda G. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 58 years old and married. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 33000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer, such as manure. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional seeds and seedlings. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support the immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds and seedlings

loans.name: Sokoin

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokoin C. is a 52-year old widow with six children. Five of them are married and another one is a garment factory worker. The family lives in a small village about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Sokoin sells grocery items at home and she is a rice farmer as well. She is asking for a loan of $500 to expand her grocery store and for growing rice.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store and for growing rice

loans.name: La Buena Amistad Group

texts.es:
En el mercado 22 D. enero ubicado en los olivos lima Perú se encuentra el puesto D. abarrotes “DORITA”  la propietaria es la Sra. Dora D. 38 años casada y con 2 hijos ella se siente feliz D. saber que todo su esfuerzo y lucha por salir adelante no fue en vano su historia D. trabajo empieza cuando una amiga le encargo su  puesto D. abarrotes para que ella lo trabaje mientras ella hacia un viaje es así que ella aprendió a trabajar en ese tipo D. negocio durante todo este tiempo le fue muy bien ahora tiene  su propio puesto  donD. venD. todo tipo D. productos como azúcar,leche,arroz, fideos y todo lo necesario para la canasta familiar. Ella no quiere quedarse en el mismo lugar por eso esta buscando trasladar su negocio a un lugar mas granD. para ampliarlo ya que su meta es ser mayorista y abastecer D. productos a las bodegas, Dora es la secretaria del grupo “LA BUENA AMISTAD” ella esta feliz porque en todo este tiempo ha visto su negocio crecer y los prestamos que ha obtenido D. EDAPROSPO fueron D. gran ayuda desD. sus inicios ahora usara su préstamo para seguir comprando productos D. abarrotes  para su negocio.

•	La Sra. Dora esta con polo morado es la séptima.
texts.en:
In the “22 D. enero” (22nd of January) market in Los Olivos, Lima, Peru is the “Dorita” grocery stall.  The stall's owner is Dora who is 38 years old, married and has 2 children.  She feels happy to know that all her effort and fighting to get ahead have not been in vain.  Her work story began when a friend put her in charge of her grocery stall so that she could make a journey. This is how Dora learned to work in the business.  The business went very well and now she has her own stall where she sells all types of products such as sugar, milk, rice, noodles and everything necessary for the family shopping basket.  She does not want to stay in the same spot so she is looking to move her business to a bigger place so that she can expand it since her goal is to be a wholesaler and stock stores with products.  Dora is the secretary of the “La Buena Amistad” (Good Friendship) group.  She is happy because over time she has seen her business grow and the loans which she has received from EDAPROSPO have been a great help from the beginning.  She will use this loan to continue buying grocery products for her business.

* Dora is the seventh lady from the left wearing the purple top

loans.use: To buy grocery products

loans.name: Sombang Lestari Group

texts.en:
Ni Kadek P. is a 32-year-old female living in the town of Melaya - Bali.  Ni Kadek is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Sombang Lestari (PK-10364).


Ni Kadek is married and has an infant-aged child.  To make a living, Ni Kadek owns & operates a business raising pigs for sale.  Ni Kadek has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 250,000 IDR a month from these activities.


In 2010, Ni Kadek joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ni Kadek has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000,000 IDR from MUK.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 1,000,000 IDR, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the first loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  Ni Kadek plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

She is very grateful for this loan, because with this loan she can get additional revenue to use to support the needs of her family and a little for savings.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation and loans, thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





Ni Kadek P. (0) merupakan 32 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya - Bali.  Ni Kadek adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 10 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah Sombang Lestari (PK-10364).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  Ni Kadek sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun.  Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Kadek menghasilkan sekitar 0,250 IDR.  Dalam 2010, Ni Kadek bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  Ni Kadek telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya sebesar 1.000.000 IDR dari MUK.  Pinjaman sebelumnya ini digunakan untuk membeli bibit ternak untuk dibesarkan & dijual di masa mendatang.  Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1.000.000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 1st pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.


  "

loans.use: To purchase baby pigs to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Mrs. Leng S. and her husband, Mr. Ang Un, have been married since 1987. They have five children; three sons and two daughters. Three of them are garment factory workers and the other two are in school. They are living in a small village approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.   

Mrs. Leng S. is a garment factory worker. Her husband is a construction worker. Mrs. Leng S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to renovate the house where she lives. This will be her second Kiva loan.

loans.use: To renovate the house where she lives

loans.name: Jafarkhon

texts.ru: Сафаров Чафархон проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 40 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Чафархон имеет среднее образование. Более 8 лет занимается животноводством. Разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. Он в основном разводит скот в дальнейшем для перепродажи. Создал все условия для расширения своего бизнеса. Он берет кредит с льготным периодом. Цель кредита является закуп крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Jafarkhon S. lives in the Hamadoni region. He is 40 years old. He is married and has four children. His wife is a homemaker. Jafarkhon has secondary education. He has been doing animal husbandry for more than eight years. He breeds large cattle at home. He mainly breeds the cattle for resale. He created all the conditions for expansion of his business. He is taking out the loan with a grace period. The purpose of the loan is to buy large cattle.

loans.use: To buy large cattle

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda Nalubega is 18 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child.  None of her children is currently in school.  Brenda has a business selling fruits, which she has had for 1 year.  She also sells tap water.

To help expand her business, Brenda has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase fruits.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Brenda hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Brenda hopes to own a salon.  

Brenda is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning how to save money.

loans.use: To purchase fruits for her fruit sales business.

loans.name: Haydee

texts.en:
Haydee E. is 54-years old, married and supports her family by operating two business ventures: fishing and being a caretaker of a fishpond businesse.  She lives in Purok Banagan, Brgy. Tomongtong, EB Magalona, Negros Occidental.  She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her fishing and fish vending businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9,000.  

Haydee is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she could purchase a new engine for her pump boat.  This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon.  Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Haydee aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase a new engine for the pump boat.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en: Marcelina J. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 58 years old. Marcelina is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Marcelina plants and harvests corn for sale. Marcelina has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2007, Marcelina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 33,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Marcelina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Norith

texts.en:
Mr. Norith P. (pictured with his wife) and his wife, Mrs. Savoeun You, live about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1996 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. All of the children are in school.

Mr. Norith P. is a farmer. He grows lotus and melon on his farmland in the village. Mrs. Savoeun You ran a grocery store, but she quit the business to assist her husband in the farming business. 

Norith asked for a Kiva loan one time already and he now is asking for another loan of $1,200 to continue his farming business by purchasing seeds, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To use for growing lotus

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en: Vergie G. is 61 years old andmarried. She supports her family by operating three business ventures: a general store, a piggery and selling rice. She lives in Purok Matea, Brgy. San Jose, EB Magalona, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, piggery and rice businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 11,000 Philippines pesos (PHP). Vergie is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she could purchase more stock of soft drinks to sell. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Vergie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stocks of soft drinks to sell to customers

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda C. is from the village of Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. She is 47 years old. Erlinda is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda sells AVON products such as cologne, lotion, watches, etc., in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month for these activities. In 2010, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas.
