Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Franie

texts.en:
Franie M. S.. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. He is 42 years old. Franie is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Franie owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Franie has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 11,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Franie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Franie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Franie is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Franie from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise.

loans.name: Fatime

texts.en:
Fatime is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For over eight years, she has operated a food stall business, selling maize flour, wheat flour, and cooking oil, operating from her home to her neighbours and passersby. Fatime faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to establish a cereals shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase two sacks of beans, a gallon of cooking oil, three bales of maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of beans, a gallon of cooking oil, three bales of maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Channy

texts.en:
Mrs. Channy S. (in the photo) is 42 years old, and her husband, Mr. Bunlay Nhem, is 41 years old. They have been married since 1991 and have three daughters. All of them are in school. They live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Channy is a farmer. She grows flowers on her farmland in the village and sells to a middleman who comes to buy them at her home. Her husband is a security guard. 

Channy is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: To repair the house where she lives

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is a 35-year-old married man with four children living in their own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His family dream is to educate his children and improve his household income. He is a special hire driver. For the last six years, he has been able to buy land. Paul is faced with the challenge of fluctuating fuel prices but this hasn’t stopped him from hoping for the best. This being the season of grasshoppers when many people make some good income, Paul intends to use the credit facility to buy lights and iron sheets for catching grasshoppers to sell.

loans.use: To buy lights and iron sheets to catch grasshoppers to sell

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en:
Mr. Cheng S. and his wife, Mrs. Srey Yin, have been married since 1980 and have five children—two sons and three daughters. They live about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.
 
Mr. Cheng S. and his wife are farmers. In addition, they also raise pigs and produce rice wine. Cheng has asked for a Kiva loan one time already. He is now requesting another loan of $1,000 to purchase additional piglets to raise and use for farming.

Photo: Mr. Cheng S. and his wife

loans.use: To buy additional piglets to raise and use for farming

loans.name: Erimiya

texts.en: Erimiya is a 24-year-old married man with one child of two years living in a rented house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has been driving a taxi for the last five years. His business dream is to get another taxi in order to increase his long-awaited family dream of improving his household income. Erimiya intends to use the loan to service his vehicle for his transport business.

loans.use: To service his vehicle for his transport business.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita C. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 54 years old. Rosita is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Rosita owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn to sell. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2007, Rosita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Rosita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita H., from the village of Brgy. Balete, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya, is 55 years old, married, and has three grown children. To make a living, Carmelita owns and operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel T. is a 22-year-old tailor in Junju Kilifi. He is a single man who has been in this business for the last two years and has done great.

This marks Emmanuel's first loan from KADET. He plans to purchase clothing materials and use the anticipated profit to plow back into his business and also to pay for his brother’s school fees.

In the future, he hopes to expand his business and increase his cash flow.

loans.use: To purchase clothing materials

loans.name: Verentino

texts.en: Verentino is a 30-year-old man, married with two children living in his own semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His dream is to educate his children, to complete his house and to have sustainable income for the family. Verentino has been a baker for three years and has seen noteworthy changes in his investments. For example, he has been able to buy a piece land amidst the challenge of fluctuating prices. Verentino needs the loan to purchase baking powder, sugar and flour for making bread.

loans.use: To purchase baking powder, sugar and flour for making bread.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en: Jean C. is from the village of Brgy. Balete, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 30 years old. Jean is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Jean buys and sells charcoal in the local community. Jean has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,200 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Jean joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jean is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Jean from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira C. is from the village of Talon, Gingoog City. She is 48 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Elvira owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling daily use products, such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, and instant noodles, in the local community. She is also buying and selling electronic loads from several networks like SMART and GLOBE. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Elvira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elvira has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI.  The previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to buy and sell. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital. This loan will be Elvira's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and acquire working capital

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco A. is 48 years old, married and has five school-aged children. He is from the village of Sinamar within the municipality of Roxas, Isabela province on the Luzon islands. Francisco raises pigs for fattening and sale. He has been in business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Francisco joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Francisco successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. Francisco is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP that will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to pay tuition fees for his children.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Serah

texts.en:
Serah N. is a 37-year-old married mother of two children. She sells cashew nuts in Kilifi and has been in business for 11 years.

Serah is requesting her first loan from KADET. With the money she plans to buy ten bags of cashew nuts for resale. Serah intends to diversify her business and purchase a dairy cow.

She hopes that this loan will help her expand her business.

loans.use: To buy ten bags of cashew nuts

loans.name: Trinitas

texts.en:
Trinitas C. is 56 years old, married and has three adult-aged children. She is from the village of Agay-ayan, Gingoog City in Misamis Oriental province on the Mindanao islands. Trinitas makes and sells snacks and other delicacies such as rice cakes and cassava cakes to the local community. She has been in business for over six years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Trinitas joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She is requesting a loan, her first from HSPFI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase the ingredients needed to make her food products. Trinitas plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand her business.

About HSPFI:

Hagdan sa Pag-uswag Foundation, Inc., or HSPFI, is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the ingredients needed to make her food products

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta M. is from the village of Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. She is 60 years old. Jacinta is single. To make a living, Jacinta owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Jacinta has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jacinta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jacinta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 18,000 PHP from ASKI. Jacinta is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand the range of products offered in her store. This loan will be Jacinta's 5th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to financially support extended members of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand the range of products offered.

loans.name: Alik

texts.en:
Alik B. is 55 years old; he lives and manages his own small shop in Ijevan City. Alik has been running his business since 2008, and his wife and his son help him in this occupation. The main line of Alik’s business is food and household goods trading, but he deals in fruits and vegetables in the spring and summer months and he sells animal fodder in the autumn and winter as well. Alik’s son is busy providing merchandise for his father's shop, and Alik’s wife helps him right in the shop.

Alik is asking for a loan of 800,000 Armenian drams to buy flour, cereals, sugar, etc. for his shop and also animal fodder to resell.

loans.use: To buy flour, cereals, sugar, etc. for his shop as well as animal fodder to resell.

loans.name: Dismus

texts.en: Dismus is a 64-year-old married man with six children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He owns a permanent house. He and his wife work tirelessly to achieve the family dream of becoming economically stable. Dismus is a renowned farmer in the village with an extensive tea plantation. Through his business, he has been able to change from subsistence farming to commercial farming. His dream is to buy more land and increase coverage of the tea plantation. Dismus intends to use the loan funds to buy tea seedlings for planting.

loans.use: To buy tea seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna B. is from the village of Sinamar, Roxas, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Lorna is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Lorna owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs and fattening them for sale. Lorna has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. Lorna is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be Lorna's 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies.

loans.name: Kitunga Tukore Group, Kihihi

texts.en:
T. Ivan is a married 28-year-old man. He is a patient and hardworking man with a retail shop in Kanyasti Trading centre. Ivan has been in this business for three years and his main duty is to ensure that it is well-stocked to attract more customers. 

In the beginning, Ivan got a small loan from a local savings and credit group to expand his business from tea growing to include a retail shop. His dream is to start up a wholesale shop with plans for continued development.

loans.use: Restocking his retail shop with more merchandise.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco C. is from the village of Libertad, Gingoog City. He is 58 years old. Francisco is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Francisco owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, detergents, noodles, and canned goods in the local community. Francisco has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Francisco joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Francisco is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be his first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more milk and bread.

loans.name: Rodgers

texts.en:
Rodgers S. is a forty-four year old dairy farmer in Kiwandani Kilifi.  He is married to Susan Karisa and together they are blessed with three children.

He is applying for a second loan KES 27,000 from KADET and he intends to purchase another dairy cow for his farm and will use the anticipated profit to educate his children.  He hopes to greatly increase his cash flow.

loans.use: To purchase another dairy cow.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 32 years old and married with three children.  She has been in business for three years selling used clothing in a good and busy environment in Machakos.  Mary is a member of Loyal group that has guaranteed her loan of KES 25,000.  

With this loan, Mary wants to add to her stock of used clothing.  She also practices farming and sells vegetables from her farm to earn extra income. She hopes to grow her business into a boutique and also get to a level of selling clothes wholesale.  She describes herself as organized.

loans.use: To add stock of used clothing.

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared C. is from the village of Poblacion, Gingoog City. She is 34 years old. Jared is single. To make a living, Jared owns & operates a business dealing and selling clothing & shoe products from AVON and NATASHA in the local community. Jared has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jared joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jared is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to buy and sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jared from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell

loans.name: Nemreh

texts.ar:
نمره عمرها 55 سنة غير متزوجة تعتمد على نفسها منذ اكثر من  26 سنة تعمل بكد                                          
ونشاط تعمل في الخياطة في المنزل لها زبائن كثر من جيرانها ومحبيها                                                         
عملها جيد جدا محبوبة ومثابرة في عملها تريد من خلال طلب من المجموعة تطوير عملها وشراء                                  
مكنة كهربائية جديدة لزيادة عملها تحلم نمره الى انشاء معمل صغير لها لكي تضمن                                           
شيخوختها فيما بعد ما يميز نمره في عملها انها تجذب الزبائن من خلال اسعارها الرخيصة لها تاريخ مشجع جدا في المجموعة
texts.en: Nemreh is a 55-year-old single, self-reliant woman. For the past twenty-six years, she has been toiling away at home as a sewing professionA.. She is popular among her customers (who come from her neighbors and friends) because she is well-liked, her work is high-quality, and she offers extremely reasonable prices. Nemreh is seeking a loan from A. Majmoua (with which she has a very encouraging credit history) to procure a new electric sewing machine to increase productivity. She also dreams of setting up a small workshop to ensure for herself an income for when she becomes too old to work.

loans.use: Purchase new electric sewing machine

loans.name: Christin

texts.en:
Christin R. is from the village of Barangay 23, Gingoog City.  She is 25 years old.  Christin is single.  To make a living, Christin owns and operates a specialized retail store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling clothing and shoe products from NATASHA and AVON in the local community.  Christin has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Christin joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Christin is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Christin from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to buy and sell

loans.name: Teddy

texts.en:
Teddy N. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has 1 child.  Her child is not currently in school.  Teddy has a stone quarrying business, which she has had for 1 year.  In addition she also sells vegetables.  

To help expand her business, Teddy has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase vegetables and stone materials.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Teddy hopes to generate greater profits and buy food.  In the future, Teddy hopes to own a retail shop.   

Teddy is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving on her business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and stone materials for her business.

loans.name: Delmar

texts.en:
Delmar A. is from the village of Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City.  He is 23 years old.  Delmar is married and has 1 infant-aged child.  To make a living, Delmar owns and operates a transportation business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle transport services in the local community.  Delmar has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Delmar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Delmar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI.  Delmar is requesting a new loan of 16,000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business.  This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Delmar from ASKI.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase equipment to improve the business.

loans.name: Madinah

texts.en:
Madinah N. is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala west region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Madinah has a business of stone quarrying, which she has had for 4 years. She does poultry  

To help expand her business, Madinah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase stone materials. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Madinah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Madinah hopes to become a teacher. Madinah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by teaching her how to work hard.

loans.use: stone materials

loans.name: Phorn's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has five people who have selected Mr. Phorn P., 35 years old, to be the group leader.  They will use their portion of the loan for different purposes located in Pouthi Reamea village in Kandal province. 

Mr. Phorn P. is a farmer who owns a 0.50-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family, while his wife, Mrs. Thary Ngorn, is a seamstress in a garment factory who has a low salary to support her family. His problem is that his wife’s work place is far away from his home. So to improve this condition, Mr. Phorn P. is seeking for a loan to buy a new motorbike, and with the rest of the loan he is going to buy rice seed. This couple has three children, who are all attending in public school.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen M., 30, is the sole proprietor of a barber shop in Mtwapa Mombasa. He is married to Caroline Steve and together they are blessed with one child. He has been in this business for the last seven years and has done great.

Stephen is requesting his second loan from KADET Ltd to buy another machine for haircuts and use the anticipated profit to expand his business. In the future, he hopes to be successful and own rental houses.

loans.use: To buy another machine for haircuts.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah N., 20, lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is single and has no children. Deborah has a business selling food in the market, namely poultry, which she has had for two years.

To help expand her business, Deborah has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chicken. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Deborah hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Deborah hopes to become a nurse. Deborah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase more chicken for resale.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan N., 18, lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is not currently in school. Susan has a stone quarrying business, which she has had for two years, as well as a salon.

To help expand her business, Susan has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase a dryer and oil treatment for her salon. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Susan hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Susan hopes to own a plot. Susan is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase a dryer and oil treatment for hair

loans.name: Timothy

texts.en:
Timothy is a divorced man with two children, all of whom attend school.  He lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water.  His greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

He has operated his pub for over three years, selling to his neighbours and passersby.  In addition he also operates a cosmetic shop contributing to his other source of income.  Timothy faces a major challenge of variability in his business.  During week days he experiences low customer turnout compared to weekends when the number of customers is high.  He hopes to expand and open a restaurant in the future.  

With the KES 15,000 he wants to purchase two crates of beer for resale in his pub.  He decided to join Yehu to get financial support to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase two crates of beer for resale in his pub.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Paulina M., who is a landlady, is 47 years old, lives in Kayole Estate where her rental houses are located. Kayole is a slum area and most of her customers are low income people but they like her houses which are built with iron sheets because they are semi-permanent, affordable and well kept.  She is married to John Kitau.

Paulina has been running this business for the last 10 years and her monthly income is KES 40,000.  She also rears pigs as her secondary business. She was introduced to KADET LTD by another existing customer and she wants to use the loan to renovate her houses so she can add to the rent amount.

If the loan boosts the business, she plans to build more houses to rent and she dreams that in future she will be able to build permanent houses to rent.
Paulina describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To renovate her houses.

loans.name: Hin's Group

texts.en:
The loan group in Anlong Ta Sek Leu village in Kandal province consists of four members, who have selected Mrs. Hin H., 54 years old, to be  group leader.  All the members will use their portion of the loan for varied ways to support their businesses to improve their living. 

Mrs. Hin H. is a Khmer cake maker who sells Khmer cake to earn profit to support her family. She is a widow who does not have a child. Although she tries to work hard, she can earn little money. So to improve her family living, Mrs. Hin H. is applying for a loan to buy some pigs for breeding to start a new business.

loans.use: To buy some pigs for breeding

loans.name: Kigandotubingye Obworo-Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Zefurino T. is 45 years old and is happily married with seven children.  He belongs to Kigando Tubingye Obworo Group- Kyenjojo. 

He has been selling crops such as maize, beans, and millet for the last 6 years in Kigando. He started this business with his own initiative. In addition to selling produce, Zefurino works as a crop farmer and also in animal rearing. All of his businesses are self-started initiatives. With this loan, he will buy more maize and potatoes for resale. 

He is a hardworking and knowledgeable man. He hopes his business will expand continuously and that he will have a stable family.

loans.use: Buying more maize and potatoes for resale.

loans.name: George

texts.en: George Y. is 34 years old and operates a tuk tuk in Kilifi. A tuk tuk is a 3-wheeled vehicle used to transport people or things. George is married to a housewife, and they support two children. He has been in this business for the last five years and his income is good. As a member of KADET, he is requesting his second loan to add to his cash-on-hand to be able to purchase another tuk tuk. He will use the anticipated profit to build a permanent house for his family. He hopes in the future that he will be able to increase his cash flow.

loans.use: To purchase another tuk tuk

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Nateete in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has three children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Rose has a little restaurant business, which she has had for five years.         

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase and stock food, charcoal, and plates.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees.  In the future, Rose hopes to own a plot of land and build a house. 

 Rose is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business sense.

loans.use: stock food, charcoal, and plates

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam N. is 17 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala west region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children. Mariam has a business selling fish, which she has had for one year.         

To help expand her business, Mariam has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more fish and cooking oil.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Mariam hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. 

 In the future, Mariam hopes to own a plot of land and build a house.  Mariam is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her business.

loans.use: more fish and cooking oil

loans.name: Haytham

texts.ar:
هيثم عمره 38 سنة غير متزوج يعمل في تعهدات الدهان واعمال الصيانة يعمل منذ اكثر من 12 سنة يحب ان يبني اسرة , له في مجال عمله خبرة واسعة لكن ما ينقصه
هو المادة لكي ينمو بعمله يحب عمله جدا له زبائن كثر من محيطه وجيرانه عمله جيد يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة شراء ارض له في البقاع لتعميرها وزيادة 
مدخوله مصلحته خاصة به لديه صعوبة في محيطه العملي من خلال المنافسة
texts.en: Haytham is 38 years old. He is single, and for more than 12 years, he has been involved in paint and maintenance works. Haytham would like to start a family. He possesses the necessary expertise to thrive but is financially challenged.  Haytham loves his job and has his own clientele, which includes his neighbors. He would like to request a loan from A. Majmoua to purchase a piece of land and develop it, thereby increasing his business income. Haytham is also challenged by competition within the field.

loans.use: Purchasing a piece of land in his hometown of Bekaa

loans.name: Kanyoe Matambo

texts.en:
Kanyoe Matambo R. is 40 years old, and he has been in the quarry business for one year in Maweni, Kilifi. He gets good income. He is married to Kanyoe Randu who is a housewife and they are blessed with four children.

He was introduced to KADET by a friend, and he is applying for his first loan of Kshs.16,000 to buy quarrying tools. He will use the anticipated profit to build a permanent house for his family. He hopes in future he will be able to increase his cash flow through KADET loans.

loans.use: to buy quarrying tools

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia M. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child.  Her child is currently in school.  Lydia has a beauty shop business, which she has had for three years.  She also sells charcoal.  

To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase oil treatment for the hair.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Lydia hopes to generate greater profits and take care of her mother.  

In the future, Lydia hopes to build rental houses and expand her business further.  Lydia is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning new games and knowing how to handle her life.

loans.use: oil treatment for the hair

loans.name: Dolores

texts.en:
Dolores A. is from the village of Talusan, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 37 years old. Dolores is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Dolores owns & operates a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling coconuts for copras in the local community. Dolores has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Dolores joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dolores has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional coconuts. Dolores is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Dolores from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Rit's Group

texts.en:
Four members make up this group loan in Samraong K'aer village in Kandal province, where they live. They all have selected Mrs. Rit H., 48 years old, to be group leader.  They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Rit H. and her husband, Mr. Taroem Ben, are farmers who own a small piece of land where they grow some rice to sell and some rice to support their family.  They own an agricultural machine. Her rice field is far away from irrigation system and has infertile soil. So to improve production, Mrs. Rit H. is applying for a loan to buy gasoline and fertilizer. She is a mother of four children, two of whom are helping their parents’ businesses, while the others are studying in school.

loans.use: To buy gasoline and fertilizer

loans.name: Joneta

texts.en:
Joneta U. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 58 years old. Joneta is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Joneta owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, junk foods & canned goods in the local community. Joneta has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Joneta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joneta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Joneta is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Joneta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson A. is from the village of Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. He is 39 years old. Nelson is married and has three young children. To make a living, Nelson owns & operates a transportation business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle transport services in the local community. Nelson has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Nelson joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelson has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. Nelson is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials to improve the business. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Nelson from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials to improve the business

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia L. is from the village of San Juan, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 50 years old. Amelia is widowed and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Amelia owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, toothpaste, and junk foods in the local community. Amelia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 9000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Amelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Amelia is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Amelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Man

texts.en: Man H., 52, is a single mother living in Phnom Penh City. She was married but her husband died several years ago. She has eight children; two are married and live away from home and the other six are single. One of them them is a hairdresser in the local market. Man H. has earned her living by selling fish in her community since 2005. She sells fish that she buys from her supplier. She also rents her house to make additional income.  Because selling fish is her main way to earn money, Man H. is applying for a loan to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase fish to sell.

loans.name: Nahila

texts.ar:
: ناهله في عمر 36 سنة غير متزوجة تعمل في مجال الملابس والايشاربات النسائية ناهله متعلمة وصاحبة طموح كبير تحب عملها وتعمل فيه
منذ اكثر من 7 سنوات هي تحب التجارة وتريد ان تتطور وان تبني لها عائلة وتكون عائلتها ذات مستوى معيشي مريح تلقى دائما دعم كبير من عائلتها لتطوير عملها 
تريد من خلال طلب قرض لها من المجموعة الى شراء بضاعة جديدة للمحل وزيادة البضاعة بمناسبة الاعياد ليس لديها اي صعوبة في التطور فهي مجدة ونشيطة
texts.en: Nahila, 36, is single. She works in the women's clothing and scarves business. She is educated and highly ambitious, with a passion for her work. Nahila has been working in this business for more than seven years. She likes trade and wishes to develop her business. Nahila wishes to build a family of her own with a good standard of living. She enjoys huge support from her family to develop her business. Nahila wishes to get a loan from A. Majmoua to buy new stock for her shop and to increase the current stock for it is now feast time and thus a selling season. Being active and a hard worker, Nahila can easily manage to develop her business.

loans.use: To buy new stock for her shop during the selling season and develop her business

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie A. is from the village of Cataggaman Viejo, Tuguegarao City. She is 40 years old, separated from her spouse, and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Josie sells rice. She is just recently started this business.

In 2010, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI and is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase rice to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Josie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase rice to sell

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Debora is a widow with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For over ten years, she has operated a food business, selling beans, maize flour, and rice from home to her neighbours and passersby. Debora faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to open a restaurant and cereal shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase a sack of beans, two bales of maize flour, and two sacks of rice.  She decided to join Yehu to get financial assistance to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of beans, two bales of maize flour, and two sacks of rice.

loans.name: Kong's Group

texts.en:
The four members of this group loan located in Preaek Ta Ong Ti Muoy village in Kandal province, have been selected Mrs. Kong C. T., 40 years old, to be the group leader. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family living. 

Mrs. Kong C. T. is a mat weaver who earns some money to support her family while her husband, Mr. Thoeun Men, is a construction worker. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand.  To improve this business, Mrs. Kong C. T. is applying for a loan to buy raw material to make mats. 

She is a mother of six children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, one is living in Japan, and the others are attending in public school.

loans.use: To buy raw material to make mat

loans.name: Muhiddin

texts.ru: Хидиров Мухиддин проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Более 5 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где сеет пшеницу. Кредит берет с льготным периодом. Целью кредита является закуп семян.
texts.en: Muhiddin K. lives in the Yavan region. He is 36 years old. He is married and has six children. He has secondary education. He has been in agriculture for more than five years. He has a plot of land by his home where he sows wheat. He is taking out the loan with a grace period with the purpose of buying seeds.

loans.use: To buy seeds

loans.name: Sim's Group

texts.en:
This group loan has five people who live in K'am Samnar Leu village Kandal province. Mr. Sim U., 52 years old, is the group leader selected by the other members.  The members will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. 

He and his wife, Mrs. Key Ket, are farmers who own a 1.5-hectare plot of land to grow rice and corn to sell to support their family.  He also does bicycle repairs.  He is now facing problems because his field has infertile soil and a lot of insects.  To improve production, Mr. Sim U. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. 

He is a father of three childR., two of whom are farmers, while the other is a student.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: M. Moses is a hardworking man and a salary earner from Kihihi. Moses is seeking a loan to be able to pay school dues for his children who are still in school, and he will be using his salary to clear the loan. He is married with 5 children, of whom two are still in school and the rest are managing their own lives. For the times that he has taken out a loan, he has been able to improve his home and he is so happy about it.

loans.use: School dues for his children.

loans.name: Leab's Group

texts.en:
This group seeking a loan consists of five people who all live in Preaek Ruessei village in Kandal province. They have selected Mrs. Leab S. L. as a group leader. All the members of the group will use their portion of the loan for different purposes, in order to improve their living standards. 

Mrs. Leab S. L. was born in 1974. She and her husband, Mr. Vai Kheang, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of land on which they grow rice to sell to support their famiL.. Mr. Vai Kheang is a fisherman. This is the season for growing rice but Mrs. Leab S. L. did not have the money to buy rice seed, so she is seeking a loan to buy rice seed. She has six children, one of whom is employed in a bread shop, while another is a duck breeder and earns a low salary. Two children are students, and the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy rice seed

loans.name: 16-01-03-Dong Hai Group

texts.en:
Hang T. T. (23) is a 25 year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Hang is the leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 03-Dong Hai (16-01-03-Dong Hai).

Hang is married and has one small child. To making a living, Hang owns a business harvesting and selling river-caught fish.  She has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 3200000 VND a month.

In 2008, Hang joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women and is now requesting a new loan of 6000000 VND which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. The loan will be the 20th she has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  L. T. Hanh (35) is a 47 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her service business. 

2.  T. T. Hai (40) is a 58 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

3.  D. T. Hong (37) is a 36 year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her fishing business. 

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Hang T. T. (23) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Hang là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 03-Dong Hai (16-01-03-Dong Hai).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ thu hoạch & bán các loại cá đánh bắt ở sông trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Hang thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 7 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Hang kiếm được khoảng 3200000 VND.  Vào 2008, Hang đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Hang đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua cá bổ sung để bán.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 20th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1.  L. T. Hanh (35) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.

2.  T. T. Hai (40) là 58 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

3.  D. T. Hong (37) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  D. việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase fish to sell

loans.name: Mackson

texts.en: Mackson T. is 35 years old and owns carpentry shop in Mtwapa, Kilifi. He is married to Lilian T. who is a housewife and they have three children. Mackson has a good history with KADET, and is applying for his second loan to purchase timber for his workshop and make desks for a school. He will use the anticipated profit to buy furniture for his house and hopes that in future he will have a very successful business.

loans.use: to purchase timber for his workshop and make desks for a school

loans.name: Yor

texts.en:
Mrs. Yor T., 53 years old, operates a small shop in her house where she has opened a coffee shop, and she also sells fish-paste for an additional fee. She typically makes around US$ 3 in profit each day to support her family needs. She was married but she divorced her husband years ago. She has two children, and both of them have different occupations. 

Mrs. Yor T. is running her business smoothly because she has skills in public relations which she uses with her customers. Presently, she wants to expand her business by buying different kinds of drinks to sell. As she lacks money to make this possible, Mrs. Yor T. has decided to request a loan from Kiva. Mrs. Yor T. will use these funds to buy more soft drinks to sell.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Kamal

texts.ar:
كمال في عمر 43 سنة متزوج وله ولد يعمل في مجال حدادة السيارات منذ اكثر من 7 سنوات له خبرة كبيرة 
في عمله يحب عائلته ويريد التطور يلقى دعم كبير من محيطه حيث انه موهوب في عمله                                         
زبائنه من محيطه وجيرانه له عشق لعمله فهو يريد من خلال طلب قرض                                                      
له من المجموعة شراء ماكنة لرش البويا ومعدات جديدة لانه يواجه صعوبة مادية لشراء بضائع لتطوير مصلحته                  
 تاريخه مع المجموعة مشجع حيث انه يواجه صعوبة في المنافسة
texts.en: KamA. is a 43-year-old husband and father of one who loves his family and wants to help them advance. KamA. has seven years experience working in an automotive bodyshop, his customers coming from his neighbors and colleagues, who give him a lot of support. He is very talented and passionate about his work. Given the financiA. obstacles he is facing in procuring new equipment to further develop his business and accordingly compete more effectively, KamA. was interested in obtaining a loan from A. Majmoua to purchase a spray painter and other new equipment. The applicant’s credit history with A. Majmoua is encouraging.

loans.use: Purchase spray painter and other equipment

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 25 years old and married with one child. He operates "Nyanza Tailoring Shop" a tailoring business in a competitive part of Nairobi. He has a reliable market and employs two people. He is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to add to his stock of fabrics. 

Julius is hard-working and hopes to expand his premises and buy a building in which to operate his business in future. Julius thanks Faulu for teaching him how to manage his business through the regular training sessions held in Faulu.

loans.use: to add to his stock of fabrics

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr:
Madame Awa C. est mariée mère de 5 enfants, âgée de 46 ans, elle est polygame et vit avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants  dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala.  
N’ayant pas eu la chance de continuer les études primaires, Awa n’a pas pris du temps pour s’accrocher aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman depuis son jeune âge et l’exerce pour elle-même il y a plus de 20 ans. Son activité principale est la vente des  chaussures, sacs et autres, elle est coiffeuse  et très bien sollicitée par les femmes de la ville de Koutiala. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce  et satisfaire sa clientèle en qualité et en quantité, Awa a fait recourt à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.  Elle est à son troisième  prêt individuel  et les deux précédents a été correctement remboursés.  
Avec ce financement elle compte acheter,  70 paires de chaussures  et 25 sacs. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako  et effectue sa vente dans la  ville de Koutiala et dans son salon de coiffure à une clientèle composée  de jeunes filles et des femmes mariées  au comptant et à crédit.  
Avec l’augmentation de son fonds de commerce, elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 175.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage d’utiliser pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts de Soro  satisfaire ses besoins entretenir ses enfants  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs Awa C. is a married mother of five children and is 46 years old. She is polygamous and lives with her husband, her co-wive and their children in the neighborhood of Hamdallaye of the city of Koutiala.

Since Awa lacked the opportunity to complete elementary school, she didn't waste time and at a young age entered upon an income generating activity with her mother. She has been in this business for over 20 years. Her main activity is selling shoes, handbags and similar items. She is also a hairdresser and her services are in great demand from the women of Koutiala.

In order to increase her working capital and meet the quality and quantity demands from her clientele, Awa came to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is her third individual loan, after having properly repaid her previous two loans.

She wants to use this loan to buy 70 pairs of shoes and 25 handbags. She gets her supplies in Bamako and retails them in Koutiala and in her beauty salon. Her customers are girls and married women who pay cash or buy on credit.

Thanks to her larger working capital, Awa expects to make a monthly profit of 175,000 CFA francs. She will use it to pay the installments of her loan, provide for herself and her children, and invest any money left over in her business.

loans.use: To buy shoes and handbags

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: T. Godfrey is a hardworking man and a salary earner from Kihihi. Godfrey is seeking a loan to be able to pay school dues for his children who are still in school, and he will be using his salary to clear the loan. He is 48 years old and married with 4 children. He is a hardworking and cooperative man, and his dream is to expand his business as well as educate all his children. Godfrey is grateful that he has been able to improve his home with the help of loans.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Chaka

texts.fr:
Monsieur Chaka D. est âgé de 46 ans marié à deux épouses et père de 4 enfants. Il loge dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala. 
Son enfance a été perturbée par des problèmes familiaux qui lui ont empêchés  d’étudier. Pour pouvoir réussir dans la vie,  il  n’a pas  pris du temps pour embrasser les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de son père depuis son jeune âge. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, il s’est intéressé à la vente de poissons fumés qu’il apprit auprès de ses amies il y a 20 ans. Les poissons fumés sont très prisés dans le milieu Miniaka puisque le prix est abordable et il peut valablement remplacer la viande  qui revient très chère. 
Pour pouvoir augmenter son fonds de commerce et renforcer sa capacité de vente, il décida de  rejoindre  l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 mois. Il est à son premier prêt individuel, qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter, 10 paniers de poissons fumés à Konna  (Région de Mopti) auprès des  pêcheurs et effectue sa vente au  marché à poisson de Koutiala,  à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’ hommes  en détail au comptant et à crédit. 
Chaka envisage obtenir un bénéfice de 180.000FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera pour le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, satisfaire les charges de la  famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr Chaka D. is 46 years old, he has two wives, and is father to 4 children. He lives in the Hamdallaye neighbourhood in the town of Koutiala.
His childhood was disrupted by family problems which prevented him from studying. In order to succeed in life he has not taken the time to engage in activities that could bring him some income at his father’s side since he was very young. Having had several unsuccessful occupations, he became interested in the sale of smoked fish, an activity that he learned from his friends 20 years ago. Smoked fish are very popular in the Miniaka location since the price is reasonable and it can genuinely replace meat which is very expensive.
In order to increase his stock and reinforce his sales capacity, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution two months ago. This is his first individual loan, which he intends to use to buy 10 baskets of smoked fish at Konna (in the Mopti region).He will purchase the fish from the fishermen and sell his goods at the Koutiala fish market to  a clientele of both men and women, retail for cash ,and on credit.
Chaka foresees a profit of 180.000FCFA per month which he will use to pay the Soro Yiriwaso interests, to meet the family needs and to invest in his business.

loans.use: Purchase of smoked fish

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr:
Natif de Safebougou, Monsieur Adama  C. est âgé de 41 ans, polygame et père de  7 enfants, il habite dans le quartier Médina coura de la préfecture de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
Du a des problèmes sociaux il  n’a pas pu continuer  les études primaires, raisons pour la quelle il s’est intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de son père. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, il finit par opter  l’achat vente des poissons fumés  il y a 14 ans. Les poissons fumés sont beaucoup prisés à Koutiala et sa notoriété est bonne.  
Pour pouvoir augmenter son fonds de commerce et renforcer sa capacité de vente, il décida de  rejoindre  l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a 2 mois. Il est à son premier prêt individuel. Monsieur Adama C. compte acheter, 5 paniers de poissons fumés  à Korientzé (Région de Mopti) auprès des  pêcheurs et effectue sa vente au  marché poisson de Koutiala  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’ hommes, au comptant et à crédit. Il compte  réaliser un profit de 100.000FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera  pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, satisfaire ses besoins  et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Adama C., a native of Safebougou, is 41 years old, polygamous and father to six children. He lives in the Medina Coura district of the prefecture of Koutiala (Sikasso region).

He did not continue beyond his primary school education because of social problems. For this reason he developed an interest in income-generating activities with his father. Having had several unsuccessful acitvities, he ended up turning to the purchase and sale of smoked fish fourteen years ago. Smoked fish is in great demand in Koutiala and he has a good reputation.

In order to increase his working capital and strengthen his sales capacity, he decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, two months ago. He is on his first individual loan. Mr. Adama C. is planning to buy five baskets of smoked fish from fishermen in Korientzé (Mopti region). He sells his fish at the fish market in Koutiala to a customer base made up of women and men, for cash and on credit. He is expecting to make a monthly profit of 100,000FCFA, which he will use to repay Soro Yiriwaso's interest, satisfy his needs and invest in his business.

loans.use: Purchase of smoked fish

loans.name: Brehima

texts.fr:
Monsieur Bréhima Berthé est âgée de 38 ans et vit dans une famille polygame avec ses  épouses et ses  5 enfants dans le quartier Lafiala  de la ville de Koutiala. 
Du à des problèmes de famille, il a prématurément abandonné l’école pour s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus depuis son enfance auprès de ses frères. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, il s’est finalement intéressé l’achat vente de poissons fumés qu’il apprit il y’a 10 ans. Les poissons fumés sont très prisés à Koutiala  puisque c’est moins cher.  
Pour pouvoir augmenter son fonds de commerce et renforcer sa capacité de vente, il décida de rejoindre  l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2 ans. Il est à son troisième prêt individuel  et  les précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Il compte acheter, 10 paniers de poissons fumés  à Korientzé  (Région de Mopti) auprès des  pêcheurs et effectue sa vente au  marché poisson de Koutiala  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’ hommes, au comptant et à crédit. 
Bréhima espère réaliser un profit de 150.000FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera  pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, satisfaire les besoins  de sa  famille et investir le reste dans son activité. 
Il compte toujours sur les financements  de Soro Yiriwaso pour pouvoir prendre en charge les frais de scolarité de ses enfants et élargir son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Bréhima Berthé is 38 years old and lives in a polygamous family with his spouses and 5 children in the Lafiala neighborhood of the city of Koutiala.  Due to family problems, he had to leave school prematurely in order to get involved in revenue generating activities during his childhood alongside of his brothers.  After having run several businesses withuot success, he finally began selling smoked fish, which he learned to do 10 years ago.  Smoked fish is very popular in Koutiala since it is inexpensive.

In order to increase his business funds and to strengthen his selling ability, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution 2 years ago.  He is on his third individual loan, having paid back the others in full.  

He expects to buy 10 baskets of smoked fish in Korientzé  (a region of Mopti) from the fishers and then make his sales at the fish market.  He has a customer base made up of both men and women, and he sells for cash and credit.  Bréhima hopes to make a profit of 150,000 FCFA per month which he will use to repay the interest on his loans from Soro Yiriwaso, to meet the needs of his family, and reinvest the remainder in his business.  He is counting on Soro Yiriwaso's financial aid to be able to pay for his children's educational costs and to grow his business.

loans.use: Purchase of smoked fish

loans.name: Mesaidi

texts.en:
Mesaidi is a widowed woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that  has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent.

For over ten years, she has operated an open air food stall, cooking rice and beans for sale. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. Mesaidi faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the rainy winter season, it becomes difficult to sell food in an open market. She hopes to establish a restaurant in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase bags of beans and wheat flour to cook for sale. She decided to join Yehu because of its good customer relations.

loans.use: To purchase bags of beans and wheat flour to cook for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: School dues for his children

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah N. is 20 years old and lives in the town of Matugga in the Luweero region of Uganda.  She is single and has two children.  Neither of her children is in school. Norah has a business rearing cows, which she has had for five years.  She sells milk.  

To help expand her business, Norah has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase feed.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Norah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. 

 In the future, Norah hopes to own a retail shop.    Norah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by improving her living standards.

loans.use: cattle feed

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr:
CHANTAL M. N.


Femme faisant preuve de responsabilité par rapport au prêt, elle a remboursée et épargnée sans problèmes.

Le prêt lui a permis de réorganiser son système de gestion, à connaître son bénéfice, à améliorer son activité ce qui lui a permis d’augmenter son capital.
Ses recettes journalières sont passées de 60000f à 150000f par semaine et elle occupée une autre table pour élargir son activité.
Avec  le prochain prêt, elle va augmentée son stock en achetant 5cartons de poisson salé morue, 5cartons de poisson salé sole, 5cartons poisson salé thons.Tres enthousiaste , elle tient a aller loin en tenant compte de ses ambitions et pense toujours travailler avec Hope.
texts.en:
Chantal M. N. is a woman who manages loans responsibly, since she has repaid her installments and saved some money in the past without any problem.

Her loan enabled her to reorganize her management system, to know her profit and to improve her activity. All this enabled her to increase her working capital. Her turnover rose from 60,000 to 150,000 CFA francs a week, and she used an additional table to expand her activity.
