loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Mr. Phorn N. (pictured here), 34, and his wife, Mrs. Kunthea Chen, 31, live in a small village along National Road Number Three about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 2001 and have two young children--one son and one daughter. 

Phorn is a motor taxi driver. His wife is a garment factory worker.  He is asking for his first loan of US$ 300 to build a kitchen for family use.

loans.use: To build a kitchen for family use

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Yim S. is a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She has a partner in her husband, a disabled person who stays at home to do the housework. This couple is married and blessed with two children. One child helps to contribute to the family livelihood by working in a garment factory. 

To make a living, Yim S. always relies on using her old bicycle to transport the used goods that she buys, going door-to-door around the commune and which she then resells to earn income. Yim S. will use her loan to purchase more items for her used-goods business.

loans.use: To purchase items for her used-goods business

loans.name: Putheary

texts.en:
Mrs. Putheary B. (pictured above) is 30 years old and lives with with her mother in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 20 kilometers away. She has full-time employment. 

Putheary does not have her own motorbike for commuting and she spends a lot of money on traveling costs. Therefore, she is asking for her first loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Sros

texts.en:
Mr. Sros S. (pictured above) and his wife, Mrs. Sithorn Bang, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 20 kilometers away from the capital. They have three children--two sons and one daughter. Both sons are in school and the daughter is married and lives outside the family home.  

Sros has full-time employment, and his wife is a garment factory worker. He is asking for his first loan of US$ 1,000 to pay school fees for his son who is attending university.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his son who is attending university

loans.name: Sarem

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarem Y. (shown in the photo) has been running a grocery store at home for more than 10 years. Her husband is assisting his wife in the business. 

Sarem asked for a Kiva loan one previous time already. She is now requesting another loan of $600 to purchase a sugar cane juicing machine and to continue expanding her grocery store.

The family lives in a small village approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase a sugar cane juicing machine and to continue expanding her grocery store.

loans.name: Loh

texts.en: Loh M., age 50, is the mother of four children. Her husband is 56 years old. He is a cloth seller, making approximately $3 per day. Loh M. sells fish, door to door, around her community in Phnom Penh City. She always gets up in the early dawn and hurries to the riverside to wait for the arrival of the fishing boats. Loh M. then makes haste to the market, where she sells her wares at suitable retail prices. This couple has four children, three of whom are single and still living with these parents. The remaining one is married and is employed as worker overseas. In order to make more income, Loh M.'s husband wants to add more capital for expanding his business. To encourage her husband, Loh M. would like to use her loan towards her husband's purchase of additional products for selling.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell.

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Phorn C. has been living in a small house from which she operates her small enterprise of selling breakfast foods to the neighbors. She is able to earn approximately $2 each day. She has other income from her husband who drives a trailer-motor taxi. This couple has given birth to two children, all of them are still single and studying in school. 

Currently, Phorn C. faces difficulties with her living situation because her house needs repairs, but she doesn’t have enough money to pay for construction fees. She is asking for a loan to repair her house. The rest of her funds will be used to change her husband’s trailer-motor.

loans.use: House repairs and towards her husband’s trailer-motor.

loans.name: Lubov

texts.en:
Lubov is divorced and has one adult son. She sells women's clothing at a big department store in Berdyansk town. Her average net income is 4,000 Grivnas per month.

Lubov started this business 12 years ago. At that time, her husband had left her and she had to raise her son by herself. Lubov is a very disciplined person and pleasant to talk to. She believes that these two qualities have helped her to develop her business and to become successful.

Lubov would like to get a loan of 10,000 Grivnas to increase the assortment of clothing that she sells. The additional income would be used for the family needs as well as for further business development.

loans.use: To increase the variety of inventory.

loans.name: Las Exitosas Group

texts.es:
Hace algunos años AdeL. inaguro su bodega “XIOMARITA” el nombre es de una de sus  hijas su negocio esta ubicado en su misma casa, desde muy niña conoció el trabajo por que su mama también tenia una bodega y durante toda su vida vio como su mama trabajaba fue de elL. que aprendió  todo sobre este negocio, después de muchos años ya casada vio que era L. mejor forma de ganarse L. vida sin descuidar a su familia recuerda que solo tenia 50 soles lo único que pudo comprar fue algunas gaseosas, un molde de keke y así en L. puerta de su casa con solo una mesita empezó lo que ahora se convirtió en su fuente de trabajo, ahora tiene una bodega muy grande con muchos clientes a los que abastece de toda clase de productos es una de las bodegas mas completas y  tiene productos de bazar, abarrotes y licores. ElL. ofrece a sus clientes el pago a crédito de esa manera mantiene feliz a su clienteL. lo que hará próximamente es ampliar su casa y convertir toda L. primera planta  en un minimarket, su préstamo actual lo usara para comprar licores ya que tiene mucha demanda de esos productos por estas épocas de celebraciones. AdeL. acaba de ser elegida L. nueva presidenta del grupo “LAS EXITOSAS”

*L. Sra.AdeL. es L. sexta de L. foto
texts.en:
A few years ago AdeL. set up her grocery store “Xiomarita” which is named after one of her daughters.  Her business is located in her own home.  She has known the work since she was a little girl because her mom also had a grocery store and during her whole life she saw how her mom worked.  It was from her mom that she learned everything about this business.

After a lot of years, when she was already married, AdeL. saw that it was the best way of earning a living without neglecting her family.  She remembers that she only had 50 soles and the only things she could buy were some cans of soda and a cake tin.  With only a little table, she set herself up in the doorway of her home and began what has since become her source of work.  Now she has a very large grocery store with many customers who she supplies with all sorts of products.  Hers is one of the most complete grocery stores around and she sells market-place items, groceries and licquor.  She offers her customers goods on credit which enables her to keep her customers happy.  Soon she is planning to extend her house and turn the whole first floor into a minimarket.  He current loan will be used to buy liquor since these products are in high demand as it is a season for celebrations.  AdeL. has just been elected as the new president of the “Las Exitosas” (Successful Women) group.

* AdeL. is the sixth person along in the photo

loans.use: To buy liquor for her grocery store

loans.name: Inna

texts.en:
Inna is married and has 4 children. She runs a small business growing tomatoes, cucumbers and other vegetables in green houses. Inna has three green houses that provide enough space to grow the vegetables. The yearly profit is 40,000 Grivnas.

Inna is a hard working and disciplined person. She would like to develop her business further. She is requesting 10,000 Grivnas to fix the green houses and to purchase fertilizers. She needs to purchase new film to cover the green houses. She hopes to use future income to improve her family living conditions.

loans.use: To fix the green house and to purchase fertilizers.

loans.name: Unidas Triunfaremos Group

texts.es:
Por mucho tiempo Elizabeth tenia un terreno en el centro D. la ciudad este solo le generaba ingresos por cochera, fueron una amigas que le dieron la mejor idea D. su vida ellas fueron desalojadas D. un mercado y al no tener a donD. ir le propusieron a Elizabeth les alquile su propiedad para poner el mercado, fue así que inauguraron el  mercado "SANTA ROSA"  donD. ella percibe alquileres mensuales con lo cual ella pueD. solventar sus gastos y vivir cómodamente, ahora esta proyectándose para techar una parte del segundo piso del mercado para alli construir cuartos para poder alquilarlos y D. esa manera tener otros ingresos, el prestamo que EDAPROSPO le otorga servirá para el pago D. un local  que quiere alquilar para D. ese modo iniciar el negocio que siempre ha querido, tener su propio restaurante uno D. sus grandes sueños por que le encanta la cocina ya cuenta con lo necesario  los utensilios y el mobiliario que es lo mas indispensable, esta muy animosa en este nuevo proyecto que espera concretar muy pronto,tambien se siente feliz D. formar parte del grupo "UNIDAS TRIUNFAREMOS" donD. ella se desempeña como secretaria.
 * Elizabeth esta con chompa verD. por otro lado aparecen 2 socias invitadas
texts.en: For a long time Elizabeth had a plot of land in the city center. Cars were parked on it and so she had some income from it. A few friends gave her the best idea of her life: they were evicted from a market place and, having no place to go, they proposed to Elizabeth to rent her plot of land to them and let them have their own market. This is how the Santa Rosa Market was established. Elizabeth receives a monthly rent which enables her to pay her bills and have a comfortable life. Currently she has a new project, namely roofing part of the second floor of the market and construct rooms for rent, and so have an additional income. The loan that was granted by Edaprospo will be used to rent premises where she will launch a new business that she has always wanted to have: her own restaurant, one of her big dreams. She loves cooking and has already all the necessary kitchen utensils and indispensable furniture. She is very spirited and hopes to make her new project come true very soon. She is also happy to be a member of the Unidas Triunfaremos Group (United We Will Have Success), where she serves as a secretary. Note: Elizabeth is the lady with the green sweater. There are two invited members pictured with the group.

loans.use: To rent premises for her restaurant

loans.name: Gualberta

texts.en:
Gualberta M., age 41, operates a specialized retail store where she sells dried fish to members of the local community. Gualberta has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 5,400 PHP a month. She and her husband live in the village of Cebunig, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. They have six school-aged children. 

In 2008, Gualberta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Gualberta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. 

Gualberta is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Gualberta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her dried fish vending business

loans.name: Houch

texts.en: Houch S., 25 years old, lives in the capital city of Phnom Penh. She earns her profit by working in the garment factory as worker. She has a fixed salary every month. This couple has just married and have only one child so far. Houch S. now lives with her mother. They have some savings in an account, but it is not enough. To solve this problem, she would like to request a loan to add to her savings to purchase a small house for living. Houch S. was not available for the photograph, so her husband is shown in the picture instead.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya is a homemaker with many household duties, but she also helps her husband in his business whenever she can. Her husband, M. A., is a cobbler by profession. He makes shoes and supplies these to different shoe shops, which place ongoing orders with him. He is an expert in his work and has been engaged in this business for over five years. 

Suraiya is the mother of five sons and a daughter. All of her sons are getting their education by attending the local school. Her daughter is 13 years old, does not attend school, and stays at home. The family lives in Kasur, a small city located in Punjab Pakistan known for its leather industry. They reside in an area named Busti Uneekan in a two-room brick house. The family moved to this area 10 years ago. 

Suraiya has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her husband in his business. With the loan, her husband will purchase leather, nails, and shoe polish in bulk quantities. These purchases will enable him to make shoes in larger quantities and fulfill orders on time. 

Suraiya is hopeful that this investment will help her husband increase his profits by making more shoes to supply to his clients. She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and this is her first loan application.

loans.use: To buy leather, nails, and shoe polish for shoemaking business

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana P., age 46, earns her living by making and selling food. She prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Juliana has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month. She and her husband have five school-aged children and live in the village of Brgy. Balete, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya.

Earlier this year, Juliana joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She wanted to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Juliana is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make her cooked food items for sale. This loan will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase the raw ingredients needed to make her cooked food items to offer for sale

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan S., age 34, is a homemaker. Her husband, Mr. Rin Chansokphally, age 45, earns a living as a motor-taxi driver. They have two children who are unmarried and are employed as workers in the garment industry. 

The family resides in a small wooden house in a rural area outside Phnom Penh City. Their living conditions are not good at present because the house is very old and in need of repair. She will use her loan to pay for these essential repairs to her home.

loans.use: To pay for essential repairs to her home

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani operates a business making "parandas," a kind of decorative hair-fastening ornament. She has been making and selling these for five years, offering them for sale not only to members of her immediate community but also to various shops at the market.

Rani has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her business through the purchase of larger quantites of necessary materials, such as colored thread and beads. This will allow her to make and sell parandas in greater quantities. She is hopeful that such an investment will further enhance her business and make her business more profitable. 

She lives with her family in Kasur, a small city in Pakistan famous for its leather industry, where she has lived for 20 years. The family resides in a two-room brick house in an area named Basti Uneekan. 
 
Rani's husband A. operates a leather-selling business. He provides leather to different shoemakers on order. His business is doing well and his eldest son helps him in his business. Their next-eldest son is 11 years old and studying in third class at school. 
 
Rani is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application. She is confident that it will prove to be a good decision for the future of her business.

loans.use: To buy colored thread and beads for making and selling "parandas," a kind of decorative hair-fastening ornament

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Sajida's Group

texts.en:
Sajida is a housewife as well as a businesswoman. In order to financially support her family, she makes 'Paranda' (an ornament used to tie back hair). She sells the 'paranda's to neighborhood customers for a good profit. 

She lives in a 3-room brick house with her family in Kasur which is a small city located in Punjab, famous for its leather industry. Her house is in the area named Basti Uneekan and she has been living here since her marriage. She has no children. 

Her husband runs a spare parts shop in the market. He sells spare parts for different vehicles and generates income for the family.  She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her 'Paranda' making business. With the loan, she will buy the necessary materials such as colored thread and beads in bulk quantity. That will help her to make the 'paranda's in larger quantity for selling. She started this business five years ago.  She is very confident about the growth of her business.   

She is a new loan applicant of Asasah and this is her first loan application.

loans.use: To buy colored thread and beads for 'Paranda' (an ornament used to tie back hair)

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei sells men's clothing at the central market in Melitopol town. He's been in this business for seven years. His kiosk has a good location, and he offers affordable prices and a large assortment. All these factors help Sergei run his business successfully. Sergei would like to borrow 10,000 Grivnas to purchase more inventory. 

Sergei is married. He hopes to make additional income to continue fixing the house where he and his wife live.  Sergei’s goal is to continue developing his small business further.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory

loans.name: Rolita

texts.en:
Rolita P. is from the village of Brgy. Balete, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 42 years old. Rolita is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rolita owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Rolita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rolita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rolita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou P. is from the village of Brgy. Balete, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 51 years old. Marilou is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a business venture selling fruits and vegetables.  Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Marilou joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Marilou from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ka

texts.en:
Ka N., age 35, is a married woman who lives in Phnom Penh City. She has given birth to four children, and all of them are single and living under her roof. To make a living, she sells fish that she buys in bulk, and she normally earns $6 per day. She always wakes up early in the morning to go where there are many fishermen working.  She buys fish and then brings them to sell at retail prices at the market. 

Ka N. is married to Rim Rouly, age 36, who shares the responsibility for his family by driving a motor taxi. He runs his business very well because he has skills in communication. Unluckily, his existing motorbike often breaks down during use. Because of that, Ka N. has decided to seek a loan from Kiva to exchange the broken motorcycle for her husband.

loans.use: To exchange the broken motorcycle for her husband's transport business

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina T. is from the village of Brgy.Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Marina is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Marina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Marina has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Marina is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Marina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

location.town: Brgy. Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Vanessa

texts.en:
Vanessa T. is from the village of Brgy. Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 28 years old. Vanessa is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Vanessa owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for breeding. Vanessa has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vanessa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vanessa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Vanessa is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Vanessa from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

location.town: Brgy. Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is a citizen of a city called Pakpattan in Pakistan. She is a talented lady who owns & operates an embroidery business to financially support her family. She is very creative in her work and crafts beautiful embroidered designs on clothes. She has a good number of clients in her neighborhood who give her regular orders. 

Her husband, M. B., is a daily wage laborer. Safia has a 3-year-old daughter, who has not yet started to attend school.  Safia’s uncle also lives with them, and he runs a "cold drink corner" in the market. He offers his customers different cold drinks like Pepsi, Coke and fresh juices. Safia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her uncle’s business. He will utilize the loan money in purchasing cold drinks and juices of different varieties to sell to his customers. He has been in this business for the past 8 years and Safia is hopeful that an investment will be profitable for him and will bring in more profits as a result. 

She is a new loan user of Asasah and this is her first loan application.

loans.use: To buy cold drinks and juices for "cold drink corner"

loans.name: Gulshan's Group

texts.en:
Gulshan lives in Pakpattan which is a small city in Punjab province, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She resides there in a 2-room brick house with her family in an area named EID Gah. She moved here after her marriage a few years ago. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to expand her husband’s business selling fruit. He started this business 6 years ago by rentng a shop in the market. From his shop he offers different seasonal fruit varieties to his customers. He has a good name in the market for his good customer dealing and reasonable rates. With the help of a loan he will put more iesf fresh seasonal fruit in his shop for selling. 

Gulshan is hopeful that with the help of an investment her husband will be able to take his business to a more profitable position and make more income which will improve his family’s financial livelihood. 

Gulshan herself is a housewife who stays at home and takes care if her household responsibilities as well as of her children. She has given birth to 2 sons. Both are very young and have not started to attend school yet. 

She is a new loan user of Asasah and hopes it will be a profitable experience for her. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Gulshan.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal fruit for fruit selling business

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick S. K. is thirty five years old and married with two children aged two-and-a-half and 13. His business is located at Bondora Kaloleni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attractions including white beaches on the Indian Ocean. 

For the past six years, Patrick has owned a cafe called Master’s Cafe where he sells drinks and food to the local people. Besides this business, he also sells clothes and vegetables. Patrick works very hard to keep his business doing well. His business is profitable but his major challenge is that his monthly capital is reduced because most of his customers buy on credit and pay at the end of each month. 

Patrick is requesting a loan of 60,000 KES to renovate his business premises and buy more foodstuff to expand his offerings and attract more customers. He hopes to grow his business into the leading restaurant that serves all kinds of food and gives exemplary customer service twenty-four hours a day.

loans.use: To renovate business premises

loans.name: Pes

texts.en: Pes P. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three of her children in the Takeo province. To earn a living, she sells bananas in the local market and is able to make about US$6 of profit a day. She has been selling bananas since 2004, and her husband is a construction worker who builds houses. Her husband earns US$3.50 each day. Three of her children are in school. Pes P. really wants her children attend the university if she can support them. Currently, she is asking for a loan of $1,200 to create a new investment. She wants to buy a store, so she can sell clothes at the market. This will allow her to make more profit.

loans.use: To sell clothes.

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita T. is from the village of Brgy. Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old. Clarita is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Clarita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Clarita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Clarita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

location.town: Brgy. Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Hun N., 40, is married and lives with her husband and three children in the Takeo province. She sells desserts in her village and is able to make about US$8 per day. Her husband raises fish and grows rice. He has been doing this business since 1999, and is able to make about US$4 of profit every day. Three of the children are in school.

To earn more money, Hun N. is asking for a loan of USD1,000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer for her husband to operate a moto-taxi. She believes the extra business will allow her family earns more income. Hun N. really wants all her children to attend the university if she can support them.

loans.use: To operate a moto-taxi.

loans.name: Ghulam Sakina's Group

texts.en:
G. sakina lives in Pakpattan, which is a small city of Pakistan known for its agricultural industry. She lives there in the area named EID Gah which is a small housing colony of the city. She moved there after her marriage 15 years ago.

She is 44 years old, and is married to M. A. who works in the fields. He grows different seasonal crops throughout the year. He works very hard day and night to get output from his fields. He also has a buffalo, whose milk he sells to his neighboring clients.

G. sakina supports her husband financially by providing sewing services. She also helps her husband in his milk selling business by taking care of the buffalo. She is the mother of 2 sons and 2 daughters. All of them are enrolled in school and getting their education.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who wants to buy some fertilizers and seeds to produce good crops in his fields. 
G. is hopeful that her husband, who has been doing this business for the past 6 years, will successfully be able to gain maximum output after this loan investment.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In her previous loan year, she has proved herself as a responsible client who has paid her installments on time and never missed a single meeting. 

This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & seeds for agriculture business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fish, maize and beans.

loans.name: Kang

texts.en:
Kang C., 30, lives in the rural area of Phnom Penh city. She is a local farmer who spends at least eight hours each day working in the field. Her husband is a domestic rice trader who buys rice in bulk from people in the village to store in his stock supply and then sell it for profit. The couple has two children who are unmarried and in school. 

Kang C. knows that her husband is having difficulty traveling to buy rice in and around her community because his motorbike is very often broken. She is therefore requesting a loan to buy a used motorcycle as a replacement.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle

loans.name: Cheng

texts.en: Cheng S., 25, a garment factory worker in Takeo Province, is able to make about US$5 of profit every day, while her husband earns US$4 employed as a construction worker. This couple has two young children living at home to support. Cheng is requesting a loan of US$1000 to purchase farmland upon which she can grow rice.

loans.use: To purchase farm land.

loans.name: Gora

texts.fr: Monsieur Gora M. est un menuisier ébéniste qui travail dans la fabrication de meubles dans la ville de Mbour. Il a une expérience de prés de 13 ans dans le domaine. Monsieur M. est un jeune qui vit avec ses parents et sollicite ce crédit pour l'acquisition de nouveaux matériaux pour renforcer son atelier ce qui lui permettra d'anticiper sur ses commandes
texts.en: Mr. Gora M. is a carpenter who works builds furniture in the city of Mbour. He has almost 13 years of experience in the business. Mr. M. is a young man who lived with his parents. He is asking for a loan in order to acquire new materials to strengthen his workshop, which will enable him to better handle customers' orders.

loans.use: To purchase materials

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao T., 44, is a widow with five children and lives in Takeo province. She sells clothes at the local market and is able to make about US$7 each day. Sao T. is asking for a loan of US$1200 to reinvest in her business by buying more clothes. (The old man who is sitting behind her is her neighbor.)

loans.use: To purchase clothes.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en:
Hun S., 33, is married with two young children living at home in Takeo province. She works in a garment factory, typically making US$3.50 each day and her husband, pictured here, is a taxi driver. Her husband typically makes about US$4 each day.

Hun S. would like a loan of US$1000 to open her new business. She has been working in a garment factory for years, so she is sure that she can open a tailor shop. This money will help her open a tailor shop.

loans.use: To open a tailor shop.

loans.name: Maqboolan's Group

texts.en:
Maqboolan helps her family financially by selling bed sheets. She purchases them from Lahore and sells to her local area customers. She has a good reputation among her clients for the good variety and quality of her bed sheets. She started this business after the death of her husband, and now her business is doing well and providing her with a regular income every month.

She lives in Pakpattan, which is a small city located in Punjab Pakistan and known for its agricultural industry. She lives in a 2 room brick house with her family in the area named EID Gah. She moved there 30 years ago. Maqboolan has 2 sons. Her elder son sells fruits. He puts the fruits on his four-wheeled cart early in the morning and sells it in different streets of the city. Her younger son works in the factory on a monthly wage. 

Maqboolan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her elder son’s business. With the loan, he will buy fresh seasonal fruits in bulk quantity to offer to his customers and increase sales. He has been doing this business for the past 5 years, and Maqboolan is hopeful that an investment will be a good step towards the positive growth of her son’s fruit selling business. She is a new loan applicant and applying for a loan for the first time.

This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Note: In the photo, the lady who has holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Maqboolan.

loans.use: To buy fresh seasonal fruits for fruit selling business.

loans.name: Souleymane

texts.fr: Monsieur Souleymane D. est un jeune qui travaille comme vendeur dans une quincaillerie.Il exerce parallèlement un métier d'électricien. Ainsi, Monsieur D. sollicite ce prêt pour l'acquisition et le renforcement de nouveaux produits ce qui lui permettra de pouvoir répondre aux demandes de sa clientèle
texts.en: Mr. Souleymane D. is a young man who works as a salesman in a hardware shop. He has a parallel business as an electrician. Mr. D. is requesting this loan to acquire and strengthen his stock of new products, which will enable him to better respond to his customers' demands.

loans.use: Purchasing stock for his hardware business

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong S., 47, is married and lives with her six children in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband works as a consultant to the commune chief making US$2 each day.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Kong S. included. Two of the children are employed, while the other four are students. Kong S. would like to take out a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Jeralyn's Group

texts.en:
Jeralyn I. is from the village of Cebu San Isidro. She is 43 years old. Jeralyn is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Jeralyn I. group.

Jeralyn is single and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jeralyn owns and operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general clothing services to local community members. Jeralyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Jeralyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeralyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. Jeralyn is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Jeralyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics & materials.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Keo S., 43, is married and lives with her five children in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband works in construction making US$3 each day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Keo S. included. Two of her children are garment factory workers and three are in school. Keo S. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret M., aged 26, is a business lady who runs a hardware business along Outering road. She sells items like tanks, cement, timber, sand and many other items in her hardware store. She is married to Harrison, who runs another hardware shop at Kariobangi estate and together they have two children, John and Ann, who are both in primary school.  Her business has been in operation for the last year and she gets a monthly income of Kshs 20,000 per month.

Margaret was introduced to KADET by the credit officer in charge of Eastlands branch. This loan will be her second loan from KADET Ltd and with the loan, plus her additional income, she will increase the stock of timber, cement and other building materials in her hardware shop. If the loan boosts the business and generates more income, she will develop her piece of land by building rental houses, which will guarantee her more security financially for the future.

loans.use: To increase stock of timber, cement and other building materials in her hardware shop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To puchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Noonkuta Ene

texts.en:
Noonkuta Ene L. is 42 years old and married to Moses L.. They have two children. Noonkuta is a farmer and she does the farming on her own piece of land, which she has been doing for the last thirteen years.

She learned about KADET from other women who are already registered as members in KADET. This will be her third loan, which she is planning to spend preparing the land for planting tomatoes. Tomatoes have been doing well in her area due to good climatic conditions and she hopes to use the profits from the proceeds of this loan to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Noonkuta’s dream is build a nice house and educate her children. Despite her age, Noonkuta is a hard working woman who is determined to achieve her set goals.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and chemicals.

loans.name: Ben (L’Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Ben est un regroupement de femmes de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien. Elles vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 42 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 3 enfants.
Ce groupe est constitué de monitrices de jardin d’enfants, qui en plus de cette profession fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les habillements,  les chaussures etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 4 ans. Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Fatoumata Berthé est un membre du groupe Ben qui vend des habits.   
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, des habits en gros. Elle se procure  des habits à Bamako. Elle vend à crédit et au comptant au grand marché de Koutiala à une clientèle diverse et variée et au niveau des structures professionnelles. 
Tandis que les membres du groupe Ben comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 160 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Fatoumata Berthé compte réaliser 190 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Ben is a group of women from Koutiala who know each other well.  They live in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives.  They are, on average,  forty-two years old, married, and have at least three children.  

This group is made up of child care workers who, in addition to this work, deal in various articles such as clothing, shoes etc. 

In order to increase their business activity, they decided to participate in the credit program through Soro Yiriwaso four years ago.  They are on their ninth group loan, having repaid all their previous loans.

Fatoumata Berthé, a member of the Ben group, sells clothing.  She plans to use her loan to buy clothing at wholesale.  She gets her clothing in Bamako.  She sells on credit and for cash at the main market in Koutiala to a varied and diverse clientele and to professional organizations. 

While the other members of the Ben group plan to make an average monthly profit of 160,000 FCFA each for this loan cycle, Fatoumata Berthé plans on making 190,000 FCFA.

In addition to repaying their loans, they will use a part of their revenue to meet daily family expenses.

They hope to strengthen this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso in order to keep their supplies well stocked.

loans.use: to buy clothing

loans.name: Khun

texts.en:
Khun S. is 33 year old married woman who currently lives in the best territory of Phnom Penh Capital. She works as a tailor who sews the villagers' clothes. She also shares her sewing knowledge with her trainees for a fee. This couple has been married for a few years, but they don’t have any children yet.

Khun S. also receives some income from her husband (pictured) who works as a motor taxi driver in and around the city. Unfortunately, an existing motorbike has broken down during driving. This is why she has decided to look for lenders on Kiva so she can replace the broken motorcycle.

loans.use: To replace broken motorcycle.

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz is married to J. and resides in Pakpattan, Pakistan, which is famous for its agricultural industry. She has been a part of this city for over 10 years.

Her husband operates a cold drink corner in the market where he sells cold drinks and juices like pepsi, coca-cola, etc. He started this business a few years ago, and it has proved to be a profitable one for him.
 
Shahnaz has given birth to a daughter and 3 sons. All of them are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education, except the youngest one who is just 5 years old and has not started to attend school. Shahnaz herself is a housewife, and prefers to stay at home and do her household responsibilities.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy more cold drinks and juices to help him increase sales and provide timely fulfillment of the needs of his customers. He has been doing this business for over 10 years and Shahnaz is confident that after this loan investment her husband’s business will grow further, making him even more money every month.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. She is a responsible client who always paid her installments on time and attended every meeting. This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy cold drinks and juices.

loans.name: Grace Ngami

texts.en:
Grace is a 43 years old single mother of two children who are all married. She has a retail shop where she sells sugar, salt, flour, tea leaves, soaps and detergents. She has been in the business for 10 years and gets a profit of KSH 20,000 per month.

This is her second loan with KADET and she intends to use it to add more stock of sugar, tea leaves and flour. She hopes to educate her grandchildren and be of help to other people by also educating their children.

loans.use: To add more stock of sugar, tea leaves and flour.

loans.name: Dembagnouma (La Bonne Mère) Group

texts.fr:
Dembagnouma est un regroupement de femmes de la ville de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien  et qui  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans, sont mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels, les condiments alimentaires de toutes sortes, des poissons, des habillements et du maraîchage. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 3 ans. Elles sont à leur septième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents  ont été bien remboursés. 
Sétou C. est un membre du groupe Dembagnouma qui vend des condiments alimentaires de toutes sortes : les épices, de l’oignon, l’ail, du Sounbala, des tomates, du sel de cuisine, de la poudre du gombo etc. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, ces condiments en gros à Bamako. Elle vend les condiments en détail et au comptant au  marché de Darsalam Koko à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Tandis que les membres du groupe Dembagnouma comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 140 000FCFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Sétou C. compte réaliser 160 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Dembagnouma is a group of women from the city of Koutiala who know each other well and live in large traditional families with their husbands, children and other relatives. They are, on average, 37 years old, married, and have at least four children. 

This group of women deals in various articles such as condiments of all kinds, fish, clothing, and fresh produce.  

In order to increase their business activity, the members decided to participate in the credit program through Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. They are on their seventh group loan, having repaid all the previous loans. 

Sétou C., a member of the Dembagnouma group, sells condiments of all kinds:  spices, onion, garlic, Soubala, tomatoes, table salt, okra powder, etc. 

She plans to use her loan to buy condiments wholesale in Bamako.  She sells them at retail for cash and on credit at the market in Darsalem Koko to a varied and diverse clientele. 

While the other members of the Dembagnouma group plan to make an average monthly profit of 140,000 FCFA each on this loan cycle, Sétou C. plans to make 160,000 FCFA.

In addition to repaying their loans, they will use a part of their revenue to meet daily family expenses.

loans.use: to purchase condiments

loans.name: Daniel Lerionka

texts.en:
Daniel M. is 23 years old from Isampin village and is married with three children who are between the ages of six and one month. He is a farmer and plants maize on his farm, getting a monthly income of Kshs 6,000.

He is currently applying for his first loan from KADET Ltd, which he will use to add maize and bean seeds for the next planting season. He will also use part of the money to pay for labour costs.

His desire is to expand his business and maximize profits.

loans.use: To buy maize and bean seeds.

loans.name: Altansuvd

texts.en:
Altansuvd B. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and infant baby in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband is handicapped and receives a monthly disability pension of 41,400 MNT. At first, she started helping her mother to make a variety of souvenirs and crafts using beads and pearls.

Since 2008, she has been operating her crafts business by herself in her home. Her husband also helps with her business. For the future, Altansuvd says, "My main business goal is to expand my business and establish a new production factory." She is a very hard working and talkative person and is requesting a 640,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of beads and pearls in order to make a variety of handicraft products.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of beads and pearls.

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad lives in Pakpattan, which is a small city of Pakistan and known for its agriculture and dairy industries. She is a working lady who operates a sewing business at her home. She sews clothes for her neighborhood clients to financially support her family. She is very skillful in her work and receives regular orders every month.

Her husband’s name is N. and he doesn’t work. She is the mother of 2 sons and a daughter. Her elder son is a rickshaw driver. He provides transport services to his passengers, while her daughter helps her in her sewing business. Her youngest son is 9 years old and stays at home. Irshad has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her elder son's business. With the loan, her son will replace the old tires with new because the old tires don’t cover longer distances and become punctured.

Irshad is hopeful that after buying new tires, her son will be able to provide better transport services to his clients and make more income. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. She is  a responsible client and has maintained a good credit record in previous loan years.

This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To replace tires of rickshaw.

loans.name: Din

texts.en:
Din O. is 22 years old, and he is a teacher in a public school in Phnom Penh City. He can earn an income of approximately $3 per day by teaching every day. He lives with his old mother who is a local farmer. Din O.’s mother has been planting a variety of crops for ten years, and she usually generates around $3 of profit a day to meet the needs of her family. The main income received from his mother's farming business is during the rice harvesting season.

Din O. needs capital for his mother to purchase many sacks of rice to store. He will sell them when the rice commands the highest price, and the rest of the loan will be used to purchase farm supplies to use on the field. Din O. was not available that day, so his mother is pictured instead.

loans.use: To purchase many sacks of rice to store. He will sell them when the rice commands the highest price.

loans.name: Ariunbileg

texts.en:
Ariunbileg H. is a 36 year old single mother with a 13 year old son. She lives with her mother and son in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic home tent, in Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. Her son attends a local secondary school. Her mother is retired and has a monthly pension of 108,000 MNT while she also receives a disability pension of 81,000 MNT due to a kidney disorder.

Ariunbileg  operates a clothes and cosmetic products retail business in her town. She sells a variety of different clothing items that are imported from Erlian, China's border city, and cosmetic products. She started her business in 2007 selling only a variety of cosmetic products, after working as a cook between 2002 and 2006. After finding success and achieving stable business operations, she started her second business of selling clothing items in 2009.

For the future, she says, "I would like to expand my business and increase my product line by offering more different kind of products with good quality to my customers. And I want to buy my own apartment." She is requesting a  3,600,000 MNT loan to purchase more cosmetic products and import more clothing items in order to increase her working capital for both of her trading businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetic products and clothing items.

loans.name: Manzooran's Group

texts.en:
Manzooran is the mother of 2 sons. Her elder son has a construction supplies business and the younger one grows seasonal crops. She is married to S. M. who is a security guard by profession. She lives with her family in a 2 room brick house in Pakpattan, famous for its agriculture industry in Pakistan. She moved there 20 years ago.

Manzooran supports her family by selling cow milk from her dairy cow. She takes care of it and sells its milk to her neighboring clients. She is also a very good housewife who does her household responsibilities very well. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help her son who wants to buy some fertilizers and seeds to get maximum output from his fields. He has been doing this business for over 10 years and Manzooran is hopeful that an investment will be more profitable for her son and his income will double.

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 4th loan application. She is a responsible client and has always paid installments on time and attended every meeting. This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Manzooran.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer & seeds for agriculture business.

loans.name: Dativa

texts.en:
Dativa is 30 years old. She is married to a motorcyclist and has two children who are between two and five years old. Dativa sells different items in her shop such as lotion, biscuits, juices and mineral waters. She has been doing this business for about three years. Most of her time is spent in her business and that is why her business prospers.  

She has requested this loan to increase her sales and buy more lotions, juices and mineral water to sell. Dativa would like to use the profits for savings. In the future she dreams of owning a prosperous business offering a variety of products to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more lotions, biscuits, juice and mineral water to sell.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 28 years old. She has one child and has separated from her husband. She has a market stall where she sells different things, but clothes are the dominant commodities she sells and she has been doing this business for about ten years. 

Jacqueline needs a loan to add more items for sale. She says that her business satisfies everything she needs, like food and clothing for herself and her child. She plans to build a house from the profits that will be obtained from this business. In the future, she would like to have a big shop composed of everything her customers may wish for.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine, 27 years old and engaged, sells various items such as slippers, soaps, plastic basins, and tooth brushes. Having spent four years in this enterprise, she is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise to sell, hoping that business profits will help her obtain a house where she plans to live.

Christine believes that having a variety of products has helped her to interact with different customers and improve the quality of service she can offer. She hopes to purchase more products and have a large retail shop in the future.

loans.use: To buy more slippers and basins to sell.

loans.name: Aimee Claire

texts.en:
Aimee Claire is 28 years old. She is married and has four children who are between five and nine years old. All of her children go to school. Aimee Claire works together with her husband in her shop that sells different items, such as beauty soap, cooking oil, hair conditioner and much more. She has had this business for five years.

Aimee Claire is requesting a loan to add more merchandise to her shop inventory. With the profit from her loan, she hopes to provide food for her family, pay school fees for her children, and be able to save money. In the future, Aimee Claire would like to own a larger shop and become a wholesaler.

loans.use: To buy hair conditioner, beauty soap, and cooking oil

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
Nida T. is a 45-year-old mother from Solong, Sibalom, Antique, Philippines. She is a loving wife to Winifredo  T., who is a farmer. They are blessed with six children. Their eldest child is already 21 years old, while their youngest is 10 years old. 

Since all of her children are still studying, they work really hard in order to provide for the needs of the family. They earn their living through a small variety store and farming. The income that they earn from this business is used towards basic needs and their children's educational expenses. 
 
As their children advance to higher levels of education, they need more money to address their educational expenses, especially for their eldest child, who is already in college. So Nida needs more capital for her business so that they earn more to sustain their basic needs.

For almost three years of membership in ASHI, she has maintained good performance because she doesn’t want to destroy the trust given to her by ASHI and its field partner. She has dreams for the future and believes only ASHI can help her achieve them.

loans.use: Additional capital for a variety store

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en: Jargalsaihan P. is 29 years old and lives with his wife and son in the Bayanhongor province of Mongolia. The family lives together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife is a salesperson in a grocery store and has a monthly salary of 200,000 MNT, while his son, age 3, stays at home. Since 2008, he has been operating sewing and wood product making businesses in his home. He also worked in the organization for project between 2009 and 2010, after completing university with a degree in accounting and economics in 2009. Currently, he plans to start operating a taxi service after purchasing a car, until he gets a new decent job. In the future, he plans to work as his occupation. Jargalsaihan is a modest and open minded man and says, "I want to save more money in order to buy a house for my family." He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a new car that will be used as a taxi.

loans.use: To purchase a new car
